item.title: 25% of KPNW Knee, Hip Replacement Patients Go Home the Same Day as Surgery
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded: Until recently, a patient having hip or knee replacement surgery could expect to spend several days in the hospital. But that’s changed with same-day total joint replacement — an effort known as Home Recovery, commonly offered by Kaiser Permanente Northwest’s Orthopedics Department. Chief of Orthopedic Surgery Jim Jackman, DO, says it’s not unusual for patients to undergo surgery in the morning and physical therapy in the afternoon — and then be home by that evening to sleep in their own beds. To make this possible, surgical techniques have not changed dramatically, but some protocols have been updated, Dr. Jackman said. Now, resources and effort that might have been expended over weeks are coordinated pre-operatively to better prepare the patient for surgery and recovery at home. The result is that patients having same-day surgery “feel like VIPs,” said Dr. Jackman. “They have a lot of touch points along the way.” A major part of successful recovery is a robust home health-care plan with the Kaiser Permanente Continuing Care Services physical therapists. They visit patients pre-operatively to assess their homes for safety and then return the day after discharge for a medical assessment, ambulation, and exercises. With same-day joint replacement becoming more common in facilities nationwide, word has spread among patients. They appreciate getting in and out of the hospital quickly, the coordinated steps pre-operatively, and new anesthesia protocols that enable safe and expedient recovery. The popularity of same-day joint replacement is the result of two efforts that occurred in tandem: adoption of Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) protocols, which started many years ago with other types of surgeries and formalized within the Total Joint program in 2017; and the organic endeavor to discharge patients sooner, which lessens the chance for complications associated with hospital stay. Currently, about 25 percent of patients receiving hip and knee replacement at KPNW go home the same day as their surgery — and Dr. Jackman expects that rate to increase going forward. These surgeries are performed exclusively at Westside Medical Center. Eventually, the hope is for same-day shoulder replacement surgeries to take place as well, and those will be performed at Sunnyside Medical Center. Gurpreet Singh, MD, an orthopedic surgeon at KPNW, talks with a patient, Cheryl, about her upcoming knee surgery.

item.title: Northwest Permanente to offer Primary Care Symposium in Salem
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded:
Register now! This fall, Northwest Permanente will offer a free, half-day education program for primary care clinicians in Salem. Heart, Dignity & Food: NWP Primary Care Symposium 2019 will take place Saturday, October 19, from 8 a.m. until noon, at the Salem Convention Center. Registration opens at 7:30 a.m., and a heart-healthy lunch will follow the conference. A light breakfast will also be provided. This year's agenda will focus on current best practices and innovations in three areas: Preventive Heart Health: Timothy Jacobson, MD, Chief of Service, Cardiology, and Andrew Pasetti, DO, Family Medicine, NWP, with Kevin Thompson, DO, Oregon Heart Center Supportive Care for the Seriously Ill: Daniel Johnson, MD, FAAHPM, National Physician Lead for Palliative Care, KP Care Management Institute, and Anna Scott, RN, Manager of Life Care Planning, Kaiser Permanente, with Nancy Boutin, MD, Medical Director Willamette Valley Home-Based Palliative Care Food as Medicine: Deborah A. Sailler, MD, and Kyla Pepper, MD, Family Medicine, NWP, with cooking demonstration by Katherine Deumling, owner of Cook With What You Have Register today over on Eventbrite!
Accreditation: The Northwest Permanente, PC, Department of Continuing Medical Education & Professional Development (NWP CME&PD) is accredited by the Oregon Medical Association to provide continuing medical education for physicians. NWP CME&PD designates this live CME activity for a maximum of 3.50 AMA PRA Category 1 Credits™. Physicians should claim only the credit commensurate with the extent of their participation in the activity. This Live activity, NWP Primary Care Symposium, with a beginning date of 10/19/2019, has been reviewed and is acceptable for up to 3.50 Prescribed credit(s) by the American Academy of Family Physicians. Physicians should claim only the credit commensurate with the extent of their participation in the activity. Disclosure Statement: All individuals with influence over the educational content of this CME activity have disclosed they have no financial relationships with manufacturers of pharmaceuticals, medical devices, or any other commercial medical products or services.

item.title: NWP physician teaches veg-based cooking class
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded: Kyla Pepper, MD, a Salem-based NWP family medicine physician, recently taught a cooking class for members at Rockwood Clinic. Dr. Pepper is a professionally trained chef who, like many of her KPNW clinician colleagues, believe that the best medicine is prevention, based upon a healthy lifestyle. Her class focused on plant-based recipes, using vegetables from Zenger Farms, which provides a weekly CSA (community supported agriculture) to some patients at the clinic. Dr. Pepper focused on three recipes, all of which take under 30 minutes to prep and cook: Millet with Lime and Cilantro (also available in Spanish here); Carrot Fries (a Spanish version is here), and Kale and Arugula Salad (Spanish version here).

item.title: Learn more: NWP Administrative Fellowships
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded:
Our program

The Northwest Permanente Administrative Fellowship Program is a premier opportunity for those interested in health care careers in medical group practice management, human resources, finance, medical informatics, provider contracting, quality, data analytics, and other administrative areas. Designed as a fast-track opportunity to transition top graduate students into leadership and specialized roles across the field of health care, the program provides:
    • Facilitated onboarding
    • Focused mentoring
    • Career-mapping assistance
    • Cross-functional assignments and high-priority projects based on individual interests and organizational needs
    • Leadership training and experience
    • Opportunities to work closely with physician and administrative leaders
    • A highly competitive salary with an extensive benefits package
    • Relocation assistance
Official Job Post Visit our job announcement page to apply.

Who is eligible to apply?

This is a highly competitive, flexible but demanding position ⁠— an excellent launch pad for those seeking a career in care delivery, operations, or administration. Applicants must be candidates for Master Health Administration (MHA),  Master Business Administration (MBA), or Master Public Health (MPH) degrees, or have graduated within 6 months of application. They must meet the following requirements:
  1. Minimum 1 year experience in a clinical setting
  2. Demonstrated knowledge of health care delivery
  3. Demonstrated ability in the areas of planning, follow-through, effecting change, project management, and leadership

Compensation

Fellows receive a competitive salary and benefits package, and accrue both vacation and sick leave. In addition, their dependents are eligible for full medical and dental benefits. Opportunities to attend internal and external educational conferences are available to current fellows.

Application requirements

  • Resume
  • 2 letters of recommendation (1 educational, 1 professional)
  • Personal statement
  • Unofficial transcripts
  • Completed online application

Timeline for 2020 applications

  • Application open: August 1 to October 11, 2019
  • First-round interviews: Mid-October 2019
  • Second-round interviews: Late October 2019
  • Final interviews: Early November 2019
  • Offer extended: Mid-November 2019
  • Fellowship duration: June 2020-21
"I am honored to be the executive sponsor of the Northwest Permanente Administrative Fellowship Program. I am invested in this program and believe in its ability to shape fellows and get them started on their journey to become effective health care leaders. I personally value and take pride in providing mentorship and guidance to our fellows. I understand the importance of recruiting top talent and shaping the next generation of leaders. "The Northwest Permanente Administrative Fellowship serves as a bridge between graduate education and real-world health management application. The fellow is exposed to all areas of our organization, is directly involved in high priority initiatives, and develops an invaluable professional network. "This is an amazing program for early careerists who are eager to learn, passionate about health management, and ready to take an important step in advancing their careers." Sincerely, Martin Zerr, VP of Administration & Business Affairs  

Have questions? We've got answers!

  • What is Northwest Permanente? Read about our company.
  • What does Permanente Medicine mean? Read about how we fit into the broader Kaiser Permanente family.
  • How does Northwest Permanente address diversity among its employees?  We place a high value on equity, inclusion, and diversity.
  • What is living in the Pacific Northwest like? There's something for everyone here!
Left to right: Dorela (Dori) Voshtina (2019-2020 fellow); Lauren "LJ" Fischer (2018-2019 fellow); Kieran Jones (2018-2019 fellow); and Ritika Jain (2017-2018 fellow).

item.title: NWP docs learn compassionate communication skills at OHSU
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded:
A few years into Northwest Permanente’s effort to improve hospitalists’ skills in communicating with patients with life-limiting illness, leaders at NWP began noticing that clinicians who trained at OHSU:
  • Show increased openness to engage in difficult conversations.
  • Take time to understand a patient’s perspective, provide concise summaries, and demonstrate empathy.
  • Use a variety of techniques to meet the patient’s readiness.
Anna Scott, MSN, MHA, RN, manager of Life Care Planning for Kaiser Hospitals and Health Plan Northwest, and NWP organizational consultant Paula Liddell, MSN, RN, shared these insights in a letter to Susan Tolle, MD, professor of medicine, OHSU School of Medicine, and director of the OHSU Center for Ethics in Health Care. Over the past two years, they said they observed “a significant difference in the communication skill set of new physicians joining our team who trained at OHSU… As the downstream recipient of your efforts and commitment to train the next generation of physicians, we want to say thank you. Your work is paying dividends to us organizationally, and, more importantly, to the community of patients and families we both serve.” Faculty help expand training to residency programs, clinical enterprise Now the OHSU School of Medicine is expanding its training in compassionate communication skills to include not only fourth-year MD students but also residents, starting by training faculty members to assist with the expansion. “The ability to effectively and compassionately share information with patients and families about what they are facing while helping them process emotions around the often-scary news helps patients take more control and make decisions aligned with their values and desires for themselves and their families,” said Katie Iossi, MD, MPH, assistant professor of medicine, OHSU School of Medicine. Dr. Iossi is among a number of OHSU School of Medicine faculty becoming Vital Talk Instructors to integrate compassionate communication into the residency programs and clinical practice. OHSU leaders are pleased to see the ripple effect that the instruction is having in the community. “We want to recognize Kaiser Northwest Permanente for their implementation of compassionate communication in their clinical practice and thank them for this acknowledgment of the work our educators are doing at OHSU,” said George Mejicano, MD, senior associate dean for education, OHSU School of Medicine. “We are excited to expand this instruction to our residency programs and hope to see our graduates continue to improve care for seriously ill patients and their families in their communities.” This story also was featured on the OHSU website.    Michael Hayes, MD, Matthew Richards, MD, Sarah Larsen, MD, (Front) Amy Robinson, MD, (Back) Kaitlin Brooke, MD, Joel Vanderschuur, MD, and Mario Padilla, MD, are all grads of OHSU’s Compassionate Communication Skills program.

item.title: NWP garners 3 'Best for the World' B Corp honors
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded: At Northwest Permanente we're celebrating this month with our fellow B Corps who have been selected as "Best for the World" Honorees for 2019. This year we were recognized as an honoree in 3 categories: Best Overall, Best for Workers, and Best for Customers (new for 2019). Northwest Permanente has been a certified B Corp since 2016. Numbering nearly 3,000, in more than 60 countries and 150+ industries, these for-profit companies are united in purpose: doing business for good — for their workers, communities, and environment. The deeds, policies, and structure of B Corps must demonstrate these values, as verified and certified by B Lab. We're directing much of our work toward "care beyond the clinic" — with a focus outward, on the communities we serve. On Forbes this week, Jay Cohen Gilbert, the co-founder of B Lab and the movement of certified B Corporations, discusses ways in which NWP and other B Corps are creating value for all stakeholders. Want to learn more? Imelda Dacones, NWP President and CEO, addressed the Best for the World recognition in a recent post on LinkedIn.

item.title: NWP physicians help staff summer clinics at work camps
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded: Every summer, local migrant camps fill with workers who help keep Oregon’s agricultural economy healthy. In turn, our colleagues at Virginia Garcia Memorial Health Center do their best to keep these workers healthy. Traveling to the camps in mobile medical clinics, these Spanish-speaking physicians provide high-quality, culturally sensitive care to hundreds of patients every summer. This year, three NWP physicians joined the effort. Anna Pierzchala, MD, Family Medicine; Eric Walter, MD, Pulmonology; and Anna Raphael, MD, Internal Medicine, all participated in the summertime mobile clinics. "Getting a glimpse at life in the migrant camp, talking to the farm workers about life in the fields this summer — all of it was very humbling. Virginia Garcia is doing great outreach work, and it felt like a privilege to take part," said Dr. Pierzchala. Dr. Walter also had a memorable experience. "I would like to do it again next year," he said. "I volunteered at Casa Blanca and Campo Bucho," said Dr. Raphael. "The latter included an asada party with free food and other supplies for the farm workers and was a lovely event. The Virginia Garcia staff and nurses were kind and great to work with, as were the VG docs I met." Through its partnerships in the community, VG is able to offer migrant and seasonal farm workers and their families a variety of resources, including access to the Oregon Food Bank, legal information, and information workers safety and rights, and pesticides exposure and safety. Northwest Permanente has a longstanding relationship with Virginia Garcia. Currently, NWP President and CEO Imelda Dacones, MD, serves on the VG Foundation's board of directors. NWP physician Dr. Anna Raphael at a mobile clinic in June.

item.title: Community giving takes 'care beyond the clinic'
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded:
How one NWP physician is making a big difference for women in Ethiopia At Northwest Permanente, nurturing the health of our communities, local and global, is at the very core of what we do. This month, until October 7, the Kaiser Permanente Community Giving Campaign is in full swing. During this campaign, Kaiser Permanente will match donations by Northwest Permanente employees to non-profits of their choice (up to $200). The following account, by Northwest Permanente urogynecologist Rahel Nardos, MD, describes one non-profit partnership that helps Ethiopian women who have a debilitating medical condition. To donate to this cause, visit Footsteps to Healing or to the Worldwide Fistula Fund. Employees can visit a secure site to donate to any non-profit organization to receive matching funds.
The two women, locked in deep conversation as if they were long lost friends, caught my attention in the hospital ward. They were in their hospital gowns laying on mattresses on the floor of the Hamlin Fistula Center in Mekelle, Ethiopia, awaiting their long anticipated surgery. I was still in my surgical scrubs, having stepped out of the operating room where I have spent the morning mentoring two of the five Ethiopian doctors who are currently in our urogynecology fellowship training program.  I sat on the floor next to the older of the two women and asked if I could talk to them for a few minutes. They spoke the local dialect, Tigrigna. The nurse translated my Amharic to Tigrigna, but the big smile on their faces told me they were happy to talk to me. The two women had met at the hospital and bonded over their shared predicament and hope of cure. I asked Tsehaitu, the older of the two women, how old she was. Her face lit up with a proud smile as she told me with confidence that she was 86 years old. Now, having been born and raised in Ethiopia myself, I know that most Ethiopians, especially those from rural communities, didn’t know their birthdays or even their birth years with certainty. Doctors often try to estimate by asking how long it has been since menopause or how old their children were. Tsehaitu however was very confident about her age saying that she was three years old when the Italians came to colonize Ethiopia, albeit unsuccessfully. This historic fact is hard to dispute and my own grandmother who is now 98 years old uses this historic year to mark her age, silencing all of us age-doubters in the family. Tsehaitu told me that she had had debilitating pelvic organ prolapse where loss of support of her vagina caused protrusion of her uterus and other pelvic organs outside of her body for the last 25 years. This is a devastating condition for women. It severely limits their ability to be physically or sexually active. They struggle with basic bodily functions such as emptying their bladder and bowel. This is made worse by the taboo around talking about this condition and the fear of not knowing what this is and why this is happening to them. Even in the United States, where women are relatively well educated and have access to medical information, patients sometimes end up in emergency rooms for fear that this thing that is protruding from their private parts is cancer. Fortunately in the United States, women have easy access to both conservative and surgical treatment and generally get help before their condition gets worse. This is not the case for Ethiopian women whose access to appropriate care for this condition is almost non-existent. Most women affected by this are from rural communities and tend to be poorly educated and have little access to medical information. They often believe that their condition is a punishment from God. Ethiopian women seem to suffer a more severe form of prolapse at younger ages as they are exposed to prolonged and sometimes obstructed labor due to lack of access to timely obstetric care. Other risk factors include multiple vaginal deliveries (a risk for pelvic floor injury), heavy physical exertion, poor nutrition, and lack of access to trained pelvic floor health providers. Tsehaitu tells me that she sought care for this condition many years ago at a referral hospital, but she was told that in order to have surgery, she needs to get someone in her family to donate blood on her behalf. This is the only way the hospital is able to voluntarily collect blood for any emergency situations that need blood transfusion. In my 11 years of doing volunteer medical work in Ethiopia, I had not heard this particular barrier to care, and I was taken aback. I asked Berhe, the second patient, how long she had had her prolapse, and she said she had had it for 10 years  — and like her friend, she was discouraged from seeking care for the same reasons. Ironically, I was relieved that they didn’t have their surgeries at that time because if they did, they would likely have received surgery from providers who have not been properly trained to repair their prolapse. Their surgeries would have likely failed, and they would have been in the same predicament. Thanks to the ongoing partnership between Worldwide Fistula Fund, Hamlin Fistula Hospitals, Mekelle University College and Health Sciences, and Oregon Health and Science's Footsteps to Healing program, they would receive appropriate surgery by skilled local surgeons who are trained in pelvic medicine and reconstructive surgery. This partnership has resulted in launching one of the first formal urogynecology fellowship programs in the country. We graduated our first two urogynecology fellows in 2018, and they are now providing training for five trainees alongside our visiting faculty. The program also includes an inter-professional team approach to care that includes nurses, doctors, and pelvic floor physical therapists. On this trip, I was deeply humbled by the unwavering commitment that our fellows demonstrated to learn and to elevate the care of women in Ethiopia. They are indeed pioneers. I have no doubt they will play a prominent role in advancing pelvic floor care in Ethiopia. Women like Tsehaitu will no longer wait 25 years to regain their dignity and health. Berhe and Tsehaitu locked in conversation.

item.title: Women in Medicine Summit attendees learn, reflect, and bond
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded:
Last week, Northwest Permanente hosted its inaugural Women in Medicine Summit ⁠— two-and-a-half days of discussion, learning, and focused energy toward reducing bias in medicine. More than 140 attendees from Northwest Permanente, other Permanente Medical Groups, and other health care systems, participated in breakout sessions and informal small group discussions over the course of the event. Three keynote speakers highlighted the conference's first day:
  • Esther Choo, MD, Oregon Health & Science University, gave the audience a "current state of affairs" of women physicians and clinicians in the medical profession.
  • Tammy Hughes, The Heim Group, presented research on gender norms as they pertain to presentation styles, approaches to negotiation, and other areas.
  • Nita Mosby Tyler, The Equity Project, helped audience members develop a deeper understanding of bias.
The second day consisted of breakouts in conflict resolution, storytelling and presentation, narrative medicine, and microaggressions. Imelda Dacones, MD, Northwest Permanente president and CEO, and Ruth Chang, MD, Vice President and Chief People Officer, served as executive sponsors of the event.

item.title: Imelda Dacones, MD, receives health care leadership award
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded: Last week, Northwest Permanente President and CEO Imelda Dacones, MD, was awarded the 2019 Health Care Leadership Award at the Portland Business Journal's Health Care of the Future event in Portland. The award is presented annually to an executive of an Oregon or Southwest Washington-based health care organization with a history of vision, leadership, and engagement on the improvement of health care practices. Dr. Dacones was recognized in part for her acknowledgment that truly integrated care cannot be attained by clinicians only, and her pursuit of cross-sectoral collaboration and partnerships to advance holistic health and well-being. Read more about Dr. Dacones' award in the Portland Business Journal.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Northwest Permanente President and CEO Imelda Dacones, MD, was awarded the 2019 Health Care Leadership Award at the Portland Business Journal's Health Care of the Future event in Portland.

Please watch for further information.*** On Tuesday, April 21, 2020, Northwest Permanente will host its all-day Clinical Educators Conference. "Opening the Door to Care: Teaching Medicine Through the Lens of History," will be held in Portland. Adam Rodman, MD, MPH, FACP, host of the Bedside Rounds podcast, an exploration of medical history, will deliver a keynote address. item.title: About: The Northwest Permanente Summer Internship program
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded:
Students: Interested in gaining valuable health care experience? The Northwest Permanente Summer Internship program may be for you.

Read the latest update on our internship program (posted March 29, 2021). Our 10-week, full-time, paid program offers positions in operational and administrative fields. [caption id="attachment_1466" align="alignright" width="500"] Teresa Meng, NWP intern 2019, presented on her experience at the end-of-summer celebration.[/caption] Administration
  • Analytics
  • Board Services
  • Brand, Communications & External Affairs
  • Business Affairs
  • Clinician Scheduling
  • Corporate Development & Systems Management
  • Finance
  • Legal Affairs
  • Medical Informatics
  • Nursing, Quality, & Service
  • Provider Contracting & Relations
  • Quality & Care Delivery
  • Talent Acquisition
  • Utilization Management
Operations
  • Anesthesia
  • Access Management
  • Cancer Service Line
  • Convenient Care
  • Genetics
  • Mental Health & Addiction Medicine
  • OBGYN
  • Ophthalmology & Optometry
  • Pediatrics
  • Primary Care
  • Specialty Care
From day one, I have experienced nothing but kindness and warmth from NWP employees. I have grown not only as an intellectual and a professional, but as a person as well. Through my involvement, I have taken a lifetime's worth of knowledge out of this internship and I'm excited to see where it will lead.
—Taylor Martin, NWP intern 2019

A comprehensive program

Our interns participate in a variety of activities The NWP internship program provides meaningful experiences for all participants — in a collegial and empowering environment. Here is some of what you can expect:
  • Projects that are imperative to department success and stem from our corporation goal and operating plan
  • 6 speaker sessions on a variety of topics (including professional communication and building a resume)
  • Physician shadowing
  • Informational interviews with executives and other leaders
  • Q & A with Imelda Dacones, MD, our President and CEO
  • Participation in a B Corp event
  • Visiting and partnering with Oregon Health & Science University to discuss higher education
  • Community building and networking
  • Mentorship
Northwest Permanente allows their interns to work on large-scale, multi-year projects. Because of this approach, we learn everything, from the organization’s big-picture group practices to management and communication skills. Everyone, regardless of position, is easy to talk to, and the environment is so inviting of personal growth and career exploration. They want their interns to succeed.
—Daniel Chen, NWP intern 2019

Eligibility

Who can apply for an NWP internship? Our summer internships will be open to students currently enrolled in undergraduate and graduate programs, and to high school students. High school
  • Must be 16 years or older and currently enrolled in school
Undergraduate
  • Have completed a high school degree or GED
  • Currently enrolled in college or university
  • Seniors graduating in May/June of 2020 are eligible to apply
Graduate
  • Hold a bachelor’s degree
  • Must be currently enrolled in a graduate program or have been accepted into a graduate program (e.g., MPH, MBA, MHA, and others)
  • Students who have a pending graduate program application are not eligible
  • Students who have completed a graduate program are not eligible
KP Scholars (students who earned a Kaiser Permanente scholarship in high school)
  • Must be a verified KP Scholarship winner and have completed their freshman year of college to apply

Timeline

What is the duration of the internship? Internships run for 10 weeks, from June through August.

How to find out about future opportunities?

2021 we will re-evaluate reopening the programs with guidance from our national and local health officials as well as leaders here at Northwest Permanente regarding COVID-19 precautions. In the meantime, we invite you to join our Talent Community where you can upload your resume and information to our database.

More about Northwest Permanente

Ours is a physician-led medical group We’re the physicians, clinicians, and administrative professionals, who serve the more than 605,000 members of Kaiser Permanente in Oregon and Southwest Washington. And we’re a B Corporation – an organization that uses business as a force for good. Come join us!

item.title: Modern Healthcare lauds Imelda Dacones, MD
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded:
Last week, Modern Healthcare included our own President and CEO, Imelda Dacones, MD, on its 25 Top Minority Leaders list:
Under Dacones’ leadership, the medical group instituted a number of clinical innovations, including protocols to reduce pediatric opioid prescriptions and screening nearly 8,000 members for social needs with over 18,000 referrals made to community-based resources. She has placed five leaders of color into executive roles to secure a 50% ratio across the company’s senior leadership.
This biennial recognition program honors top health care executives who are influencing the policy and care delivery models across the country. Joining Dr. Dacones on the list is Bechara Choucair, MD, Senior vice president and chief community health officer, Kaiser Permanente.

item.title: Climate change: ‘In our lane’ as physicians
item.dc:creator: jimthomson
item.content:encoded:
By Imelda Dacones, MD Late last month, I was scheduled to present at the World Health Care Congress (WHCC) on the physician’s role in addressing climate change. Of course WHCC, like so many other events, was cancelled due to the COVID-19 crisis. As a health care community, we’ve come together rapidly to address COVID-19 and are learning a great deal about the need for resilience. Today, on Earth Day, let’s come together to fight the equally daunting global threat of climate change. Northwest Permanente’s Climate Action Plan underscores 2 of many critical needs that have been acutely realized in the COVID-19 pandemic — the need for redundancy in our supply chains, and the need to place our vulnerable populations front and center.  Thank you to the World Health Care Congress for hosting this important conversation online. Climate change is not just a political challenge, an environmental concern, or an economic issue. It’s a crisis that hits us all, as people, as individuals, as citizens of planet Earth – because it’s about our health. Millions of lives have been lost and will be lost to hunger, malnutrition, severe droughts, storms, and heatwaves, with many more left behind as survivors – forever changed and impacted with disability and psychological trauma from financial ruin, displacement, and homelessness. Expanded territories of vector-borne illnesses like Zika, malaria, and Lyme disease will affect a growing number of people. Margaret Mead once said, “Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world. Indeed, it’s the only thing that ever has.” As physicians, we have much we can do to reduce the causes and mitigate the effects of climate change. It starts with us. We need to educate ourselves about climate change and, in turn, educate our patients and our communities, as we do every day in exam rooms and at bedsides across the country and around the world. At an organizational and systems level, our impact can be even greater. As an industry, the U.S. health care sector accounts for nearly 10% of all greenhouse gas emissions. If health care was a country, our global emissions would rank 13th in the world, right ahead of the United Kingdom. When it comes to climate change, we physicians have a critical role, voice, and influence. As a B Corp, our organization, Northwest Permanente, believes businesses can be a force for good – for people, communities, and the environment. We have like-minded physicians, physician shareholders, and staff who, within our integrated program, Kaiser Permanente, help us realize these values every day.
We need to educate ourselves about climate change and, in turn, educate our patients and our communities.
To help focus our efforts, our company created a climate action plan that identifies 8 focus areas where we believe our medical group can shift our practices to minimize our carbon footprint, leverage our voice as physicians to educate and influence climate action, and most importantly, address the impacts of climate change on our patients. Let me share one example of how we know we can make a difference. Over the last 2 years, our anesthesiologists have made an intentional switch from desflurane, an inhalational anesthetic, to sevoflurane. Why did we do this? Released into the atmosphere, desflurane can remain for more than 20 years and act as a greenhouse gas, damaging the Earth’s ozone layer and contributing to global warming. Sevoflurane, in contrast, lasts for just over 1 year, and is as effective as desflurane. A midsize U.S. hospital would use 1,000 liters of desflurane per year, or the equivalent of average annual emissions from 1,200 cars. By implementing a sevoflurane-first policy and avoiding desflurane as anesthetic in general anesthesia surgical cases, our Northwest Permanente anesthesiologists, certified registered nurse anesthetists, and Kaiser Permanente anesthesia teams have been able to reduce total greenhouse gas emissions from 1,308 metric tons in 2017, to 228 metric tons in 2019, or a reduction of 83%, with no change in patient outcomes or costs. This significant reduction exemplifies the principles of Permanente Medicine, which empowers physicians to find solutions that are best for our patients and for the health of all communities. Step by step, we can all pitch in to address climate change.

item.title: Northwest Permanente's 2019 Benefit Company and Impact Report
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_967" align="alignleft" width="214"] Dr. Imelda Dacones[/caption] Welcome to Northwest Permanente's 2019 Benefit Company Report. As we approach our 75th anniversary, our mission and vision as a medical group remains unchanged, even as the demands of our practice are constantly evolving. Our goal is to deliver total health to the patients and communities we serve and do it with compassion and integrity. We strive for medical excellence and continually seek innovations to care. We know that health is about more than what happens in our hospitals or clinics. More than 60 percent of health outcomes are determined by how and where we live, work, play, and age. The air we breathe, the food we eat, the water we drink, the roofs (or lack of) over our heads, and the love and care of our family and friends. In 2019, we made some bold moves to address these social and environmental determinants of health. We were the first major medical group in the country to launch a climate action plan, which identifies eight focus areas where we believe we can shift our practices to minimize our carbon footprint, leverage our voice as physicians to educate and influence climate action, and most importantly, address the impacts of climate change on our patients. We also took the lead as the first region within Kaiser Permanente nationally to implement Thrive Local, a bold new social care strategy designed to close the gaps our patients experience in meeting their basic social needs. This report is a snapshot of our progress on these fronts and others. None of it would be possible without our growing network of community partners. We know we have work to do, to help ensure a better future for all of us. Thank you for being a part of it. Imelda Dacones, MD CEO and President, Northwest Permanente

item.title: Jeanne Mowry, MD, honored for her work with children with kidney disease
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded: NW Kidney Kids, a local organization dedicated to improving the quality of daily life for children with kidney disease, has honored Northwest Permanente pediatric nephrologist Jeanne Mowry, MD, with a lifetime achievement award. As the 2020 recipient of the John Barry Award, Dr. Mowry is recognized for her dedicated service to children with kidney disease. [caption id="attachment_33657" align="alignright" width="240"] Jeanne Mowry, MD[/caption] The award was presented on Saturday night, during a virtual gala. Dr. Mowry, who sees patients at East Interstate and in the hospital at Doernbecher, joined NWP in 2003. She came to Oregon from Southern California in 1994 to work as an assistant professor in pediatric nephrology at Oregon Health & Science University. In addition to her clinical work, she has served as assistant chief of pediatric specialties, the OHSU medical student pediatric liaison, and the resource steward for pediatrics, among other roles. NW Kidney Kids is commending Dr. Mowry, but likewise she praises the organization for its important work in the community, providing kids who live with kidney conditions opportunities to meet one another and provide peer support. "Adults living with kidney disease have a lot of resources, but this is the only local organization that supports children with advanced chronic kidney disease," she explained. "The work they do is very meaningful to kids." Dr. Mowry has volunteered with the organization, and NWP pediatric urologist Aaron Bayne, MD, currently serves on its board.

Students and future interns: Stay connected!

At Northwest Permanente we understand that summer internships and mentoring programs are integral to your growth toward becoming a working professional.

The summer internship offers invaluable experience working in our offices and clinics and gives you valuable perspective on what it’s like to work within Northwest Permanente’s equitable, innovative, and inclusive culture.

Our top priority at Northwest Permanente is your safety, which is why we made the challenging decision once again to cancel our summer internship, mentoring, and administrative fellowship programs for 2021.

We remain hopeful that we will be able to resume our program in 2022.

In the meantime, we invite you to join our Talent Community, and stay connected with us on LinkedIn about what is happening at our organization. We want to keep you, as students and prospective interns and fellows, aware of what the future holds at Northwest Permanente.

Thank you for your continued interest in our medical group. We look forward to the future with you.

item.title: The Ideal Practice Model: Which Medical Practice Model Works Best for You as a Physician?
item.dc:creator: jimthomson
item.content:encoded:
Physicians: Find out which medical practice model is the right fit for you

Whether you’re a new or experienced physician, you have many options when choosing a career path, but the first thing you’ll want to do is identify the type of practice you want. Here are your main options:
  • Private (or solo) practice
  • Group practice
  • Hospital-based practice systems
  • Health Maintenance Organizations (HMOs)
  • The Kaiser Permanente Model
There are advantages and drawbacks to each. When deciding, you’ll want to weigh risks (as in a private practice) with lack of autonomy (as in group practice, hospital-based practice, or HMOs), as well as other considerations.

Private (or solo) practice:

Physician-owned and managed medical practices in which physicians oversee their patients’ care and must maintain the business of their practice 
  • Many physicians are attracted to the decision-making autonomy solo practice offers. But take note, a physician in private practice does assume all professional risk, including full financial liability.

Group practice:

Typically, two or more physicians sharing resources including staff, investment, and profit
  • Group practices are often divided into single-specialty and multi-specialty practices, generally providing patient care within the same facility. Group practice provides a team-based approach to decision-making and financial risk, but it is important for physicians in a group practice to weigh compatibility in practice and business.

Hospital-based practice systems:

Physicians employed by a hospital and working in a hospital-owned practice or within a hospital department
  • This model generally offers a predictable schedule and well-rounded, reliable compensation and benefit packages. Due to the size and scope of most hospital-based practices, there is generally less flexibility when making scheduling decisions, or negotiating practice parameters.

Health Maintenance Organizations (HMOs):

Physicians provide care for insurance group members
  • Most often, HMOs are insurance providers that contract with physicians, hospitals, and clinics. Generally, HMO models minimize the administrative burden of providing patient care, while providing physicians a dearth of resources. Although HMOs can make the business of medicine easier, scope of practice is often more narrowly defined, which may mean less autonomy for the physician.

One more option (The Kaiser Permanente Model):

Finally, there is another opportunity that incorporates the advantages of an HMO or hospital-based system with some of the advantages of group practice in that physicians can become partners in the group: Kaiser Permanente. Kaiser Permanente is the largest integrated, multi-specialty managed care organization in the United States, incorporating three integral groups: the Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, one of the largest nonprofit organizations in the country; Kaiser Foundation Hospitals; and regional, physician-owned Permanente Medical Groups. The Kaiser Permanente model is an integrated care delivery system with an emphasis on preventive care. Northwest Permanente is the regional Permanente Medical Group in Oregon and Southwest Washington. We practice Permanente Medicine as the largest physician-governed, independent, multi- specialty medical group in the region. With more than 1,400 clinicians, 50 medical and dental offices, and 2 hospital facilities, Kaiser Permanente Northwest provides you with the opportunity to create and grow within a sustainable practice. See yourself here? Please check out our job offerings.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Ideal Medical Practice Model | A Guide for Physicans | NW Permanente
Physicians: looking to identify which practice model is right for you? When deciding, you’ll want to weigh the advantages and disadvantages to each.

item.title: Medical networking tips for physicians
item.dc:creator: jimthomson
item.content:encoded:
Developing connections through physician networking

Once you have explored the various types of health care systems and practice models available, how do you find an opportunity? If you haven’t done so already, now’s a perfect time to start tapping into your network — the people you already know or are connected with. Once exclusively a word-of-mouth and in-person practice, medical networking today is in many ways easier than ever, but the array of venues can be overwhelming. When it comes to your career, not all medical networks are created equal — you need to determine what types of networking opportunities work best for you. Networking is a way for physicians to develop connections across fields of interest and to foster a stronger community. With a well-connected network, you will be in a better position to enhance your job search and give back to others. Regardless of how you decide to engage with a network, being an active participant will generate greater opportunities for you to make more connections. As a physician, you will be in high demand from all types of employers. Having a network that you can trust is one of the best ways to support your career growth and open doors to new opportunities that are right for you. Here are some ways to begin or enhance your physician networking journey:

1. Social media platforms for physicians

Staying connected on social media platforms such as Instagram, Facebook, TikTok, and Twitter is relatively simple and engaging. In addition, professional-focused sites such as LinkedIn or Doximity, KevinMD offer career-focused and professional networking opportunities. Knowing what type of engagement fits your style and personality is the first step toward having a positive networking experience.

LinkedIn groups for physicians

  • Medical Doctor (MD) Network
  • Doctors Hangout
  • Marketing & Networking for Business professionals and Doctors

Physicians on Doximity

Connect with licensed physicians on Doximity, the "largest community of health care professionals in the country."

2. Health care networking for physicians

In-person networking

Although not an option during COVID-19, career fairs and conferences are a great way to directly connect with potential employers. These events may be focused on Continuing Medical Education or career-specific events, but they are also an opportunity to meet with an internal recruiter or other company representatives. Hopefully, these events will come back in the future because they are great opportunities to connect with physicians who work at organizations you are targeting for employment. Follow the Northwest Permanente events page to stay up to date on future in-person career-fairs and conferences. We also invite you to join our Talent Community to stay informed of future in-person events with Northwest Permanente.  

Virtual networking events: Health care conferences and seminars during COVID-19

There are many social networking platforms but we are also in the golden age of virtual career fairs where you are able to network with employers, ask questions around their organization and find out more information about open opportunities. The impacts of COVID-19 have had a profound effect on how associations and health systems engage with employee prospects. Virtual conferences and information seminars from organizations are fast becoming the best way to “meet up.” Other ways to connect are through organized career fairs by companies like Practice Match, Practice Link, and CareerMD. At Northwest Permanente we hosted our own virtual speaker series "Lunch With Our Leaders" where you will have an opportunity to hear from our CEO and other leaders in our organization regarding topics that are important to you as a Physician. We also invite you to join our Talent Community to stay informed of future virtual events with Northwest Permanente.  

3. Alumni networks

One great way to learn more about opportunities and health systems is from friends and colleagues by word of mouth. Leveraging alumni from your university and training experiences has the added benefit of creating a sense of connection to others who have had a shared experience. It may also give you a sense of comfort that you can trust. Find ways to connect with alumni online and in-person.

4. Recruiter networks

This specifically applies to connecting with recruiters at organizations you are interested in joining. Northwest Permanente Internal Recruiters are your gateway to connect with department leaders and to learn about the culture and benefits of our organization. These contacts can help you stay abreast of opportunities. The internal recruiter should be able to update you when they have opportunities and can connect you to other resources within the organization.  

A few important details

A little about us: Northwest Permanente is the regional Permanente Medical Group in Oregon and Southwest Washington. We practice Permanente Medicine as the largest physician-governed, independent, multispecialty medical group in the region. With more than 1,400 clinicians, 50 medical and dental offices, and 2 hospital facilities, Kaiser Permanente Northwest provides the opportunity to create and grow within a sustainable practice. Kaiser Permanente is the largest integrated, multispecialty managed care organization in the United States, incorporating three integral groups: The Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, one of the largest nonprofit organizations in the country; Kaiser Foundation Hospitals; and the regional, physician-owned Permanente Medical Groups. The Kaiser Permanente model is an integrated care delivery program with an emphasis on preventive care. See yourself here? Please check out our physician job offerings.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Medical Networking Tips for Doctors | Northwest Permanente
With a well-connected medical network, physicians are in a better position to enhance job opportunities. Here are some ways to begin your journey.

item.title: NW Permanente helps care for our Latino/a/x patients with Salud en Español [podcast]
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded:
In a recent internal podcast discussion highlighting National Hispanic Heritage Month, our Northwest Permanente CEO and President Imelda Dacones, MD, spoke with three family care physicians about Salud en Español — a comprehensive Kaiser Permanente Northwest program that focuses on caring for our region's Latino/a/x population. Within these seven modules that are located within larger KP clinics, all of the physicians and clinicians, as well as nurses, navigators, support staff, back-office staff and others, speak Spanish. Created in part to help address the health disparities that our Latino/a/x community faces regarding diabetes, cancer, heart disease, and other conditions, these clinics within clinics help to build trust. "Our Spanish-speaking Latinx patients can really find that their heritage is honored and that they can feel comfortable using Spanish as their primary language — and also they know that there's going to be cultural sensitivity there," says Aaron Hanson, DO. Patient-centered care is a hallmark of Permanente Medicine. We invite you to listen to this discussion about one way that Kaiser Permanente Northwest is meeting patients where they are — to provide total health care.

Host

Imelda Dacones, MD, is president and CEO of Northwest Permanente. Dr. Dacones leads more than 1,700 physicians, clinicians, and administrative staff at the largest independent, physician-led, multispecialty medical group in the region. Together, these physicians deliver Permanente Medicine — evidence- and value-based health care with humanity — to more than 600,000 Kaiser Permanente members. She is a passionate advocate for addressing the social and environmental determinants of health, and is working to transform the culture, practice, and business of medicine. Under her leadership, Northwest Permanente became the world’s first physician group to be certified as a B Corp — underscoring a strong corporate commitment to use business as a force for good.

Guests

Saskia van der Wal, MD, is a family medicine physician who has been with Northwest Permanente since 2015. She is the NW Physician Clinical Library Lead and Salud en Español NW Regional Physician Lead. She was born in Sweden and grew up on the island of Puerto Rico, where she attended medical school. She came to the mainland U.S. for residency at University of California San Francisco, then worked for eight years with the Latino underserved population at an urban community clinic in East Oakland, California. Dr. van der Wal is passionate about practicing full-spectrum family medicine and has dedicated her career to reducing health disparities and advocating for the Latino community she serves. Aaron Hanson, DO, is a family medicine physician who also has been with Northwest Permanente since 2015. Dr. Hanson completed his undergraduate studies at the University of Washington. Before attending medical school, he worked as an orderly in a 3-bed hospital on the Southern coast of Palacios, Honduras. He completed medical training from Western University in Pomona, California, and was class president at medical school and chief resident of his residency program in Downey, California. Dr. Hanson was the medical director of the Chemawa Indian Health Center for three years before coming to Kaiser Permanente Northwest. He enjoys biking and exploring trails of the Northwest. Juan Munoz-Oca, MD, is a family medicine physician at Cascade Park Medical Office. He was born and raised in Mendoza, Argentina, and attended medical school in his hometown at the National University of Cuyo. He completed his internship and family medicine residency at Manati Medical Center in Puerto Rico, then moved to Washington to be close to his family. Dr. Munoz-Oca believes that communication is an essential part of the relationship between patient and doctor, and is enthusiastic about serving the Latino community. Read more about Northwest Permanente's commitment to equity, inclusion and diversity and advancing culturally competent care among our communities.

item.title: How NWP physicians are advancing excellence in breast cancer care
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded: By Imelda Dacones, MD CEO and President, Northwest Permanente October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month. On average, every 2 minutes, a woman in the United States is diagnosed with breast cancer; 1 in 8 women in this country will be diagnosed with breast cancer in her lifetime. Breast cancer doesn’t discriminate — in 2020, an estimated 2,620 men will be diagnosed. In a recent 365 Days podcast I had the privilege to talk with Northwest Permanente’s Margaret Bower, MD, one of our general surgeons whose practice specializes in breast cancer care, part of the service line helping our breast cancer patients here at Kaiser Permanente Northwest. Our Same Day Surgical (mastectomy, in this case) Home Recovery Program allows patients to recover from their (mastectomy) surgery in the comfort of their own homes. This program tremendously increases patient satisfaction, with more than 90% of our same-day mastectomy patients expressing excellent care experience. I invite you to listen to our discussion. Finally, please remember to complete your self-exams monthly and contact your primary care clinician/physician with any concerns.

item.title: Lunch With Our Leaders: Northwest Permanente virtual speaker series
item.dc:creator: jimthomson
item.content:encoded:
Northwest Permanente invites you to join the three part ACCME-accredited virtual speaker series Lunch with our Leaders!

Residents, fellows and practicing physicians are invited to join NWP Chief People Officer Ruth Chang, MD, and other Northwest Permanente leaders to engage in a conversation around the future of health care and what it means to practice in a physician-led, physician-owned, and professionally managed medical group.

SESSION I: Healthcare of the Future DATE: November 20th, 2020 TIME: 12:15-12:45 p.m.[Completed] SESSION II: Medical Informatics DATE: December 4th, 2020 TIME: 12:15-12:45 p.m. [Completed] SESSION III: Social Determinants of Health DATE: December 11th, 2020 TIME: 12:15-12:45 p.m. [Completed]
 

Lunch with our Leaders overview:

Series host: Ruth Chang, MD, is the Chief People Officer, Vice President for the Advancement of People and People Operations at Northwest Permanente (NWP).  Dr. Chang leads wellness and resilience; equity, inclusion and diversity; and talent acquisition and development strategies for this physician-led, self-governed, multispecialty group practice, providing care to the more than 620,000 members of Kaiser Permanente in Oregon and Southwest Washington.  Dr. Chang is a family medicine physician. She joined NWP in 2005, and through the years has served in various leadership roles. Dr. Chang received her bachelor’s degree in Women’s Studies and Mathematics from Tulane University and her master’s in Public Health and her medical degree from the University of Michigan. She completed her residency at Oregon Health & Science University.  She serves as the Immediate Past President of the Board of Directors of the Oregon Academy of Family Physicians. She also serves on the board of directors for Two Rivers Aikikai, a non-profit martial arts school in SE Portland. In her free time, she enjoys studying martial arts, playing music, and cooking with her two teenage boys and husband.

SESSION I: The Future of Health Care [completed]

This session will provide physician participants inspiration to reflect on their practice today and re-imagine, re-engineer, and re-invigorate their practices of tomorrow.

November 20th, 2020 - 12:15-12:45PM

Guest speaker: Imelda Dacones, MD, CEO of Northwest Permanente, P.C.  leads more than 1,700 physicians, clinicians and administrators at the largest independent, physician-led, multi-specialty professional corporation in Oregon and southwest Washington. Together, these physicians deliver Permanente Medicine — evidence- and value-based health care with humanity — to more than 600,000 Kaiser Permanente members. Dr. Dacones is a passionate advocate for addressing the social and environmental determinants of health, and is working to transform the culture, practice, and business of medicine. Under her leadership, Northwest Permanente became the world’s first physician group certified as a B Corp – a status that underscores a strong corporate commitment to use business as a force for good. As the recently-elected chair of The Permanente Federation’s National Permanente Executive Committee, Dr. Dacones has responsibility for the people of The Permanente Federation.  As a member of the Board of Directors of the new Kaiser Permanente School of Medicine, she looks to impact the medical education of future generations of physicians in this country in order that they spread the mission to provide high-quality, affordable health care and improve the health of people and our communities.
Recording of Session 1 (11/20/2020):
[video width="1280" height="720" mp4="https://nwpermanente.com/wp-content/uploads/RecordingTrimTrim.mp4"][/video]

 

SESSION II: Medical Informatics: The Differentiator in a Clinical Practice [completed]

This session will describe the critical role and advantages of medical informatics in providing high quality and cost-effective care to our patients.

December 4th, 2020 - 12:15-12:45PM

Guest speakers: Dr Michael McNamara, MD is a pediatrician and Chief Medical Information officer at Northwest Permanente. He began his career with NWP 26 years ago with the vision of caring for his patients in a collaborative and caring environment, with quality and service at the forefront.  All these years later he is able to blend that passion in caring for patients with the dynamic, everchanging and critical role of the medical informatics to shape and design systems to best serve Physicians and teams. Kathy Poteraj, RN is a registered nurse and serves as the Director of Medical Informatics for Northwest Permanente.  Starting as a medical assistant her career has evolved to include inpatient and outpatient nursing, helping lead the implementation of the Electronic Health Record at KPNW in the early 1990s and serving in multiple roles with a relentless focus on not only optimizing the electronic tools but ensuring that physicians and clinicians receive support to use them most effectively in their daily care of the patient.

Recording of Session II (12/4/2020):

[video width="1280" height="720" mp4="https://nwpermanente.com/wp-content/uploads/Session-II-Lunch-With-Our-LeadersTrim-1.mp4"][/video]

SESSION III: Social determinants of health - patient impact, resource network and health outcomes [completed]

This session, participants will be able to define a Social Health practice and recall what an integrated medical-social care system looks like.

December 11th, 2020 - 12:15-12:45PM

Guest speakers: Briar Ertz-Berger, MD is an emergency medicine physician and the Director of Special Populations for Northwest Permanente.  Dr. Ertz-Berger’s work focuses on eliminating health inequities and the effects of unmitigated socio-economic struggles.  Her passion for this work started with serving patients in the Bronx during medical school and continued at OHSU during her residency and subsequent research fellowship where she studied the impact of Medicaid cuts on emergency room utilization.  Now with Northwest Permanente, P.C.,  Dr. Ertz-Berger is leading work to improve the health outcomes of Kaiser Permanente Northwest members and the surrounding community through a robust Social Health program, which includes the development an Oregon-wide integrated health and social care network. Tracy Dannen-Grace, joined the community benefit department of Kaiser Permanente Northwest (KPNW) in 2004, and currently serves as Director, Community Partnerships and Philanthropy in Community Health. During her tenure with KPNW, she has assumed positions of progressive leadership and is a member of the executive team responsible for KPNW Community Health investments of approximately $160 million annually. Areas of responsibility include fostering collaborations for safety net partnerships, community-clinic integration, engaging KPNW’s 12,000 employees in community service, and partnering with local government and nonprofit organizations to disseminate assets within the community where KPNW investments will make the greatest impact.

item.title: The nexus of climate and health: Never let a crisis go to waste
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded:
BSR 2020 Annual Conference

For the first time in our lifetime, the entire global community is impacted by the same grave threat — COVID-19. The solidarity of this moment has led many to rise to the occasion in unprecedented fashion — governments have committed trillions to support industries and jobs affected by the global shutdown, and companies and philanthropists have directed billions toward finding therapeutics and supporting vulnerable frontline workers. This response must also be applied to the climate crisis. There is evidence that the growing threat of climate change will increase the frequency and severity of pandemics, and that the impact of these crises will disproportionately fall on poor and minority communities — further deepening economic inequality that is at the root of social unrest. On October 21, Colin Cave, MD, Medical Director of External Affairs, Government Relations and Community Health for Northwest Permanente, joined Ailun Yang, of Bloomberg Philanthropies, and Chhavi Ghuliani, of BSR, in a panel discussion at the BSR 2020 Annual Conference to discuss the triple crisis of climate, COVID-19, and racial inequities and the confounding impact on public health. The panel explored lessons learned from COVID-19 and how rebuilding efforts can and must consider a just transition to a green economy. Dr. Cave and his co-panelists discussed:
  • The links between public health and climate change, where we saw these links play out in the COVID-19 pandemic, and what this tells us about the future of pandemics we must prepare for
  • Some of the underlying systemic failures COVID-19 brought to the surface that are also relevant to the climate crisis — such as racial and gender inequities, and equitable access to health and education.
  • Rebuilding post-COVID-19: how must we bring these lessons to the forefront so that we are building more equitable and resilient societies and communities.
With research indicating that the impact of climate change could be 10 to 15 times greater than the impact of COVID-19, we must get the rebuilding effort right. Dr. Cave focused on the responsibility of the health care sector to take action on both racial justice and climate change — noting that more than 60 percent of health outcomes are due to social and environmental factors. Addressing these issues is critical in delivering total health to our patients, especially as the pandemic and associated economic impacts, as well as record-setting wildfires and extreme weather events, continue to impact the physical and mental health of our communities. For more information about the actions Northwest Permanente and Kaiser Permanente are taking to address climate change and social health:
  • Northwest Permanente's Climate Action Plan
  • Kaiser Permanente's Total Health For All and first carbon-neutral health system in the U.S.
  • Black-owned businesses receive $250K from Kaiser Permanente Northwest

item.title: Northwest Permanente named Healthiest Employer
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded:
Northwest Permanente has been named an Oregon Healthiest Employer, by the Portland Business Journal. This is the sixth year in a row the NWP wellness program has been recognized in the top 3 for a company of its size. The NWP wellness program is led by Norma Steiner, MD, a role she shared with Suzanne Deschamps, MD, until recently. Justin Pfeifer provides administrative direction. The wellness program, whose mission is to support the well-being of members of the medical group and staff — and to cultivate joy at work — has been consistently lauded for its excellence. Among its many facets are a new Peer Support program for clinicians; the popular, incentivized "Wellness Passport"; and, at present, myriad online courses and events.

A champion of well-being

In her role as Northwest Permanente Chief People Officer, Ruth Chang, MD, oversees the NWP wellness program. Portland Business Journal recently featured Dr. Chang on its pages: Northwest Permanente is physician-led and professionally managed. Tell us what that means. We are a professional corporation that is physician-owned and physician-led, supported by a talented pool of administrative staff. We’re the largest physician-led and governed multi-specialty group in Oregon. Our medical group is part of the care-and-coverage integrated program you know as Kaiser Permanente Northwest. Unlike other models — where physicians are employed by an insurance company or hospital — NWP physicians are owners and have the opportunity to become shareholders in the company. We serve more than 600,000 Kaiser Permanente patients in Oregon and SW Washington. Physicians in NWP practice medicine and hold leadership positions across the medical group. These leaders are the subject matter experts who make decisions on how we best care for our patients, and they also live by these decisions in their day-to-day practice. This approach is best for both patients and doctors. How does wellness fit into the values of NWP? At our company, compassion is one of our core values, and we consider it key to caring for our patients, our colleagues, and ourselves. This also builds on our strategic priorities, which focus on care experience, quality, affordability, and the well-being of the care team members. We know that clinician burnout is a major issue, and we want to address it by building a culture of wellness and creating programs to support wellness. NWP is the first physician-led medical group to be certified as a B Corp. Why is this important to the mission of NWP? In the continuous evolution of medicine, we provide integrated, value-based care. Being a certified B Corp means we are using our business as a force for good. We care not only for our patients and communities, but we’re also thinking globally about the environment. We have our own climate action plan and our own corporate social responsibility plan, and we are corporate sponsors for Reach Out and Read, Forest Park Conservancy, and Meal on Wheels. And last but definitely not least, we recognize that for the best care of our patients, it’s not only about delivering quality health care but it’s also about addressing their social needs, such as food, shelter, and transportation. What does it mean to you to practice at NWP? As a family physician I’m confident that I give great care to my patients because I can ask my specialty care colleagues for a chart review or call them for an opinion in the moment. This saves the patient time, allows for me to learn, and provides care coordination on the spot. My practice day goes smoother, it provides an excellent care experience, and at the end of day, I feel good about the high-quality care my patients receive. That’s the power of our integrated system. And, as woman practicing medicine and an immigrant to this country, I consider NWP’s commitment to building a culture of inclusion invaluable. The ability to practice high quality, well-coordinated care reduces burnout and makes me feel like I’m well supported in a team and ultimately allows me to have a long fulfilling career as a physician at NWP.

item.title: Top 10 questions to prepare for your physician interview
item.dc:creator: jimthomson
item.content:encoded:
Interviewing for a new career can be a daunting undertaking. Proper preparation is essential for anyone seeking employment. This applies to especially physicians, for whom the application and interview process tends to be more rigorous. Even the most experienced physicians can benefit from a better understanding of what medical groups are looking for in an interview. Once you've defined what your ideal practice model is and landed an opportunity for an interview, it’s time to start preparing.  

Top 10 questions to prepare for your physician interview:

  What do you know about the medical group? Always come prepared to speak to Recruiters and Hiring Managers about your knowledge of the organization you are interviewing for. Demonstrate to the interviewers that you are invested in learning more about their organization and about the opportunity you are being offered. Example: “Northwest Permanente is the Medical Group for Kaiser Permanente and has approximately 1,500 physicians across most specialties. One of my friends from Residency has worked for your practice for the last eight years. He speaks highly about the integrated model on a regular basis.”

Why do you want to work for our medical group? Let the interviewers know you are interested in this opportunity because the organization aligns with your core values. Example: “Kaiser Permanente’s philosophical approach to care is patient-centric. I chose medicine to make a difference in the lives of patients. Practicing at Northwest Permanente would allow me to put my patients first.”

Why did you leave/why are you leaving your current position? If you have already left a previous position, be honest about your reasons but avoid being negative or too personal. If you are currently employed, keep the focus on what you are looking for and what you hope to gain from a new position. Example: “I enjoy my current practice – my partners are great! However, my husband and I would like to relocate to the Northwest, so our children can grow up with their cousins nearby.” “I enjoy my current practice – my organization is great! I’m looking for a company that is focused on being a force for good such as climate change and that has leadership opportunities. From my research, Northwest Permanente aligns with my core values, and I’ve seen many of your physicians have a lot of opportunities to advance their career.” New to the Pacific Northwest? Read about living and working in the Pacific Northwest. Why should we give you this job at our medical practice? This is a common interview question but can be used to make an impact. Be sure to summarize your experience and how it aligns with the role you are interviewing for and how you can fill the organization’s needs. Example: “With five years of family medicine experience in a fast-paced, urban practice, I have had excellent patient satisfaction scores. I’m confident I would be a great addition to your family medicine team.”

What are your short-term and long-term goals? For this question, it is best to focus on concrete, short-term and mid-term objectives rather than long-term goals. Example: “I am interested in joining an organization where I can develop a progressive, patient-centered practice. Beyond developing strong relationships with my peers and specialists, my long-term goal is to further develop my leadership skills to support the organization in a mutually beneficial way.”

What makes you stand out from other candidates? For a question like this, it is crucial to revisit your unique skill set and the passions that inspired your initial application to the practice opportunity. How will these benefit the medical group? Example: “I am bilingual in Spanish and English. Additionally, I volunteer as a physician for medical missions to South America annually. As a result, I have developed the necessary cultural competence to effectively care for and communicate with Spanish-speaking patients and family members.”

As a medical professional, how do you work to improve patient care? This question provides the opportunity to show the interviewer that you are committed to patient-centered care, and it’s something you take seriously. Make sure to provide concrete examples of how you would approach it. Example: “I find that effective communication with patients plays a vital role in the quality of their care experience and in their overall health outcomes. I am intentional with each patient interaction to listen and reflect on what I have heard. If I can help them feel heard and understood, I am one step closer to cultivating a true partnership in their care.”

How do you deal with stress in the workplace? Physician and clinician practices can be stressful. Make sure to include ways you manage your day-to-day stressors as well as what support you are looking for at the organization. Example: “Currently, I work out 5 times a week and practice meditation and mindfulness. I find that physical activity and being present in my body helps reduce my stress levels. Through managing my stress levels, I am able to show up as my best self for my patients and my family.”

What can I expect to hear from your references in terms of strengths and weaknesses? The simple act of reflecting on this question before completing an application, allows you to coach your references on what could be helpful in their comments. For instance, if you are applying for a practice that has a Suboxone niche, asking your references to highlight this skill set with potential employers could set you up for success. During the interview, this question will afford you the opportunity to initiate a detailed conversation about the great things you bring to the organization as a physician candidate. If you’ve had past mishaps that might appear in referencing, this also gives you the opportunity to address them and place a positive spin on it. Example: “My references will likely comment about my Suboxone certification and my enthusiasm to build a Suboxone clinic in our Eastside clinic. They may also say that I’m an overachiever and can put too much on my plate at one time.”

Do you have any questions for us? This question provides an excellent opportunity to show that you are invested in the opportunity and have had a chance to think over how it would align with your practice and future goals. Example: “Could you describe the abilities and characteristics of physicians who are considered to have a high potential for advancement within your organization?”   Tip - make sure to email the team that you interviewed with to say thank you and reiterate your skillset and why you are the best fit for the position.   And remember developing connections through physician networking is a great way to make sure your options are always open.   See yourself at Northwest Permanente? View our current opportunities.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Top 10 questions to prepare for your physician interview
Even the most experienced physicians can benefit from a better understanding of what medical groups are looking for in an interview. We're here to help!

item.title: KPNW, alongside our area partners, opens mass vaccination site
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded:
This week, Kaiser Permanente Northwest launched a mass COVID-19 vaccination site at the Oregon Convention Center (OCC). Wednesday's opening was the culmination of two weeks of intense collaborative effort among Northwest Permanente physicians, in sync with our Kaiser Foundation Health Plan and Hospitals colleagues here in the Northwest region, and multiple partner organizations — Legacy Health, Oregon Health & Science University, and Providence Health and Services. Going forward, the OCC site will provide vaccinations to individuals in the wider Portland metropolitan area, and could ramp up to as many as 7,000 shots per day, depending on vaccine supply. Congratulations to all of the many people who worked tirelessly on this historic collaboration. As our CEO and President Imelda Dacones says, "This is a moment filled with hope — defined by true collaboration, science, and readiness that will propel us forward in our fight against the pandemic." Read more in local media: Oregonian
