item.title: Xenophobic disturbances in the Asian American and Pacific Islander communities
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_1719" align="alignnone" width="1024"] A recent headline from Oregonlive, Portland, Oregon[/caption]

A letter from our CEO and President, Imelda Dacones, MD

Last week, members of our communities suffered from a series of violent attacks targeting Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders (AAPI) In San Francisco, Vicha Ratanpakdee, an 84-year old senior was brutally assaulted during his morning walk and died as a result of his injuries. In Oakland, a 91-year-old Chinese elder was assaulted and pushed to the ground. In San Jose, a 64-year-old Vietnamese grandmother was robbed in broad daylight, just days before the Lunar New Year celebrations. Here in our local Portland, Oregon, community, incidents include physical assault of AAPI community members using public transit and reports of vandalism to 9 Asian-owned businesses in the Jade District. These incidents are not isolated. Since the beginning of the pandemic, our AAPI communities have suffered from dangerous xenophobic rhetoric that has perpetuated negative stigma and violent acts based on the origin of COVID-19. Our AAPI communities continue to experience an increased wave of violence targeting many of our most vulnerable populations, particularly elderly immigrants. As an organization that advances equity, inclusion, and diversity for all, including our Asian American and Pacific Islanders, Kaiser Permanente does not condone the behaviors driven by xenophobia, sinophobia, and yellow peril that plague our communities. These behaviors cause significant physical and emotional harm, stress, and trauma to AAPI families and communities. Together, we stand with our AAPI community to work towards dismantling anti-Asian racism to create safer, more equitable communities for all. Injustice anywhere and threat to any group anywhere are a threat to justice and other groups everywhere. As an immigrant, as a Filipina-American in this country for more than four decades of my life, I know we can do better. And we must. Like Amanda Gorman, I believe “If we merge mercy with might, and might with right, then love becomes our legacy and change our children’s birthright.”

item.title: Pitching in: A shout out
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded: When wave after wave of COVID-19 surged in Southern California in January and early February, Northwest Permanente (NWP) physicians — in a heartening show of Permanente goodwill and spirit — worked to help ease the strain on their counterparts at Southern California Permanente Medical Group (SCPMG). A couple dozen of our NWP physicians redeployed with SCPMG physician teams in varying capacities — both in-person and virtually: hospitalists, palliative care physicians, critical care specialists, and others. And many did so beyond their usual work hours. These clinicians helped to care for patients diagnosed with COVID-19, as well as those with other care needs. While those clinicians were at the forefront of this redeployment effort, many teams were involved along the way — including those who backfilled while colleagues were on the job elsewhere. From Scheduling and Credentialing to the Legal team and Employee Health, not to mention HR, Finance and Practice Directors — a huge team effort made it happen. Their work made a difference for patients in Southern California and to our Permanente colleagues who have faced and continue to face many COVID-19 related challenges on the job. Thank you everyone! [caption id="attachment_1723" align="alignnone" width="620"] A few of the NWP physicians deployed at Downey Medical Center in January: Susan Mikkelsen, MD, Critical Care; Steve Knox, DO, Anesthesiology; and Christine Choo, MD, Critical Care. "We are the ones who physically are at Downey, but it’s on the shoulders of many people lifting us up so we can help," said Dr. Mikkelsen.[/caption] Listen to an recent audiocast of NWP CEO and President Imelda Dacones, MD, in conversation with Dr. Evgenia Krotova and Cylia Amendolara about NWP palliative care physicians’ deployment to Kaiser Permanente Downey Medical Center in Southern California. They describe how these physicians scheduled dedicated shifts for a few hours to huddle with the local teams who triaged services. With an advanced virtual medical center, they were able to involve interpreters, call the families, join multiple family members on one call, call IT support, and provide all the necessary care and attention for Southern California palliative care patients.

item.title: Dr. Megan Dudley wins recognition for building community in Ridgefield
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_1727" align="alignright" width="242"] Megan Dudley, MD, winner of Kaiser Permanente's 2020 David Lawrence Award for Service.[/caption] Congratulations to our own Longview-Kelso-based pediatrician, Megan Dudley, MD, for winning the 2020 David Lawrence Service award, given by Kaiser Permanente. Dr. Dudley was recognized for her work to bring a pair of community programs and events to her town of Ridgefield, Washington. Ridgefield is a rapidly growing agricultural community with a diverse population that resides on indigenous land. Dr. Dudley's interest in community building is rooted in the past. Her grandparents met at a Japanese internment camp during World War II in Arkansas. After the experience of the camps, families were scared to share their background, stories, language, and traditions with their own children, friends, and communities. This led Dr. Dudley to want to provide a space for families today to share their stories. With that motivation, she founded and runs the Ridgefield chapter of Meaningful Movies, a nonprofit that presents documentaries, followed by a forum for respectful discussion. The purpose is to gather, educate, advocate, build meaningful and sustainable community, defend justice, and work for peace. These film events are attended by people of all ages and in the past have helped to support Ridgefield's downtown core by partnering with a local historical theater. One of their largest panel topics to date was on opioid addiction, which had 9 panel members, including several from NWP and KP along with local nonprofits. [caption id="attachment_46121" align="alignleft" width="300"] Dr. Dudley at the Ridgefield Multicultural Festival.[/caption] In addition to Meaningful Movies, Dr. Dudley a few years ago established the annual Ridgefield Multicultural Festival, which highlights Ridgefield’s heritage and cultural diversity through food vendors, dance, classes, and music. Her goal has been to create a safe event that made everyone feel like a welcome part of the Ridgefield community. She’s even recruited other NWP physicians who are a part of the Ridgefield community, such as Olubukola Okafor, MD, to become involved in this daylong event. About this award: The David Lawrence Service Award is named in honor of David M. Lawrence, MD, a former chairman and CEO of Kaiser Permanente and lifelong advocate for improving health. Kaiser Permanente makes a $10,000 charitable contribution on behalf of each winner to the nonprofit of his or her choice.

item.title: NWP physicians discuss the rich opportunities of Black History Month
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded:
Northwest Permanente physicians Carl Anderson, MD, Reva Ricketts-Loriaux, DO, and Mandrill Taylor, MD, join host Imelda Dacones, MD, NWP president and CEO, for a conversation commemorating Black History Month.
  • Regardless of our own cultural and ethnic background, how might we increase our own awareness about the breadth of Black experience in the United States?
  • How can we foster allyship and engage with other communities to lift each other up?
  • What are some ways we can actively educate ourselves, diversify our own knowledge?
Tune in for this idea-packed conversation, on PermPod. item.title: Our efforts, our impact: Northwest Permanente's 2020 Benefit Company and Impact Report
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded:
What a year! We will not soon forget its challenges and, yes, rewards. Our 2020 impact report [pdf] shares highlights of our evolution through 2020 — from global pandemic to record-setting wildfires, and through a major social justice reckoning — and highlights the impact we made, all working together.

The incredible upheaval over the past year sparked innovation in how we facilitate total health for Kaiser Permanente members andthe communities we serve. Northwest Permanente led the work to create Kaiser Permanente at Home, a revolutionary new "hospital without walls" program that enables our patients to receive hospital-level health care at home instead of at the hospital — with the love and support of their families nearby. We facilitated an exponential increase in telehealth visits for our patients, saving valuable time while keeping them safe during a global pandemic. This increase in virtual visits also contributed to lower greenhouse gas emissions from reduced travel, which has helped us to minimize our impact on the environment.

We renewed our commitment to support our community partners — to help close gaps in meeting the social needs of our patients and community through our programing, strategized giving, and volunteerism.

As we look back on 2020, we are fueled by hope and guided by our values to continue to show up for our patients, community, and environment — and our own colleagues. As each day brings us change, we use that as a catalyst to proceed with creativity and a sense of empowerment to build a new normal with the hallmarks of compassion, courage, inclusion, and innovation.

Preparedness, agility, and resilience are critical as we go forward. In order to deliver on our mission, we need to be able to deliver care to our patients, no matter what challenges come our way. Our medical group has remained dedicated, flexible, and strong through 2020, and we welcome 2021 with open hearts, lifted by the possibility of a brighter future together.

[caption id="" align="alignleft" width="214"] Dr. Imelda Dacones[/caption]

Imelda Dacones, MD, President and CEO

item.title: Join us for Permanente Women in Medicine
item.dc:creator: jimthomson
item.content:encoded:
We’re in this together

Registration is now open for the first-ever Permanente Women in Medicine event in June. We’re inviting all Permanente physicians to join us to celebrate, empower, and connect our women physicians, clinicians — and their allies — in medicine.

What: An online opportunity for Permanente physicians and guests to celebrate, be empowered, reconnect, and heal

Cost: Free

When: Events over a 4-hour window daily, June 11-13

Who's invited: All Permanente physicians and guests — all genders

Permanente Women in Medicine will feature compelling guest speakers, including Michele Harper, MD, author of the New York Times bestseller Beauty in Breaking, and Maysoon Zayid, writer, actor, comedian, advocate, and founder of the Arab-American Comedy Festival — discussions with women leaders, live entertainment, and more.

Please visit the Permanente Women in Medicine event website to learn more and register.

item.title: Happy Doctors Day!
item.dc:creator: carolynallison
item.content:encoded: Happy National Doctors Day! Every year, on this day, March 30th, I write a Doctors Day letter in celebration and recognition of all of you—my colleagues, partners and friends. While inspired by you, this note has come to be a milepost of sorts for me. For one thing, it’s become an intentional pause and time of reflection—on our profession, on my own journey as a physician, and, of course, on our journey together year-over-year. The bookends of March 30, 2020, to today, March 30, 2021—last year’s and this year’s Doctors Days— betray a spectrum of professional extremes for all physicians. While already bound together by our calling, the COVID19 pandemic has united us like never before. Fear for our own and our loved ones’ lives never loomed so large—hour-by-hour, day-by-day, from one shift to the next. All the while, we put those fears aside to keep our focus on the care of the patients in front of us. [caption id="attachment_1769" align="alignright" width="400"] Celebrating Doctors Day 2021[/caption] These four words, “Happy National Doctors Day,” almost seem glib amidst all the trauma we have experienced—the pandemic’s toll in death and suffering we experienced with our patients, their families, and, for some colleagues, our own family and friends; the far-reaching personal and financial devastation that has resulted; and not to mention the racial and social justice reckoning ignited by public murders of men and women of color. Our own mental health and resilience have never been so fragile or more wounded. But, perhaps it is because of all this that National Doctors Day is taking on new meaning this year. It must. Beyond celebrating and recognizing our contributions as physicians to individuals, to communities, and to the advancement of medical science and research, let this 2021 National Doctors Day be the year we doctors celebrate each other and celebrate our calling. We will heal from this past year’s trauma—not alone, but together. And just as we’ve demonstrated magnificently, painfully, and selflessly that we can combat this pandemic, so can we, together with our communities and patients, dismantle the systemic injustices that perpetuate poor health outcomes and inequities, and fuel moral injury and burnout for many of us. I am your ally, as you are mine. We are colleagues, partners, and friends. And we are still and always will be in this together. “Wherever the art of medicine is loved, there is also a love of humanity.” —Hippocrates Thank you, Doctors, for all you are and for all you do,     Imelda Dacones, MD, President and CEO

item.title: Happy World Health Day 2021!
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded:
April 7 of each year marks the celebration of World Health Day. From its inception at the First Health Assembly in 1948 and since taking effect in 1950, the celebration has aimed to create awareness of a specific health theme to highlight a priority area of concern for the World Health Organization. The theme around this year’s WHD is building a fairer, healthier world, something that we at Northwest Permanente work toward every day. We know that where you’re born and live, plus other socioeconomic factors, have a huge impact on your health. Here are some ways that NWP is living out our mission and working to improve the health of the communities we serve.
  • In 2020 we adopted universal social health screenings. It is our goal to screen 90 percent of our members within three years on four core issues: financial hardship, food insecurity, housing instability, and transportation
  • We also launched Thrive Local/Connect Oregon, which connects our patients to other non-medical resources in their communities. This goes beyond screening, because we cannot have healthy communities without doing more to addresses the social determinants of health
  • We will continue our work as environmental leaders in the health care industry. We know the impacts of climate change negatively affect the health of our patents, and that communities of color are impacted at a higher rate. We have committed to being carbon neural by 2025 and are constantly reviewing our practices and implementing greener programs.
These are just a few of the ways we are committed putting in the work to create a more fair and just health system leading to better health outcomes for everyone.

item.title: Perm Pod: Healthy Birth Initiative Program
item.dc:creator: jimthomson
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_46337" align="alignright" width="600"] The team behind the Healthy Birth Initiative.[/caption]

 “HBI came into my life at a time when I didn’t feel like I had much support. The encouragement, health and parenting education, and the genuine support I received, helped me to have a positive pregnancy and a good birth outcome.”

—HBI mom

Regardless of income status, Black women experience disproportionate negative health outcomes in pregnancy and postpartum. According to the National Institutes of Health, rates of maternal morbidity and mortality (MMM) are much higher in the United States than in its peer nations. National severe maternal morbidity (SMM) rates have nearly doubled over the past decade, and the incidence of SMM was 166% higher for Black women than White women from 2012 to 2015 (NIH, 2020). How are we at KP addressing this discrepancy? The Healthy Birth Initiative is an Afrocentric and nurse–family partnership program within Multnomah County that addresses Black maternal health and Black infant morbidity disparities. This program offers transportation, mental health support, family planning, multi-generation involvement, childbirth classes, and everything between for mothers throughout their pregnancy and 18 months after giving birth. In this episode of Perm Pod, our President & CEO, Imelda Dacones, MD, speaks with NWP physician Autumn Davidson, MD, and Roberta Hunte, PhD, Assistant Professor at the Portland State University School of Social Work, about the importance of this program, how racism is poison to our health and our wellness, and how this program can empower our patients.

“I find when I talk about maternal health, or when I talk about some of the issues affecting black women, white women will say, ‘Well, yeah, I had a stillbirth or I had something happen,’ and they’ll even talk about an experience where they were mistreated, but they will treat it like, well, that happened. Like Girl, get mad. Get mad. Get active. Right. Our country is not performing as well as it needs to in relation to maternal health. Get it and work together.”

—Roberta Hunte, Ph.D.

Guests: 

Autumn Davidson, MD, is an OBGYN physician and has been with Northwest Permanente since 2017. She completed her medical training on the East Coast and her post-graduate work in Chicago. At the University of Illinois at Chicago, she worked as the Family Planning clinic director, taught clinical obstetrics and gynecology, and conducted clinical research.  Here at Kaiser, she continues to work in Family Planning and also cares for pregnant people with substance use disorders through Kaiser’s Project Nurture program.  Dr. Davidson I feels privileged to care for women at all phases of their lives, and enjoys working with a diverse patient population.  She believes that the social and emotional well-being of women is as important as the biological one, and that healthy women are the foundation of healthy families, and by extension, healthy societies Roberta Hunte, PhD, MS, is an Assistant Professor at Portland State University's School of Social Work. She is a Black feminist scholar with an emerging concentration in maternal and child health disparities, with particular interests in Black maternal health. Dr. Hunte’s recent work has explored Black people who can become pregnant’s perceptions of the impacts of racism-related stress on their physical and mental well-being, and the ways Healthy Birth Initiatives (HBI), a culturally-specific perinatal public health initiative, has helped mitigate this stress. She has published on topics related to Black tradeswomen, reproductive justice, and the use of performance for cultural change. Dr. Hunte teaches on issues of Black life in the United States, intersectionality, social justice, and sexual and reproductive justice.
item.excerpt:encoded: In this episode of Perm Pod, our President & CEO, Imelda Dacones, MD, speaks with NWP physician Autumn Davidson, MD, and Roberta Hunte, PhD, Assistant Professor at the Portland State University School of Social Work, about the importance of this program, how racism is poison to our health and our wellness, and how this program can empower our patients.

item.title: Celebrating Earth Day in the work we do every day
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded:
We know that Earth Day should be a mindset we live in all year round, and as a B Corp and an environmental leader in the health care industry, we at Northwest Permanente have done our best to do just that. Here are ways in which we’ve actualized our Climate Action Plan (CAP) since its release in 2019:

2020 carbon offsets

  • 76% of our carbon emissions (3,211 metric tonnes) were offset through purchases in three certified carbon reduction projects:
    • Capricorn Ridge Wind project
    • Rainier Farm Biogas Project (in the NW)
    • Winston Creek Forest Carbon Project (in the NW)
NWP joined with over 500 other B Corps and pledged to become carbon neutral by 2030. Our goal is to hit that mark by 2025!

What else have we done?

  • By implementing a Sevoflurane-first policy and avoiding Desflurane as anesthetics in general anesthesia surgical cases, the anesthesia team has been able to reduce total GHG production from 1,308 tonnes CO2 in 2017 to 228 tonnes CO2 in 2019. This is a 1080 tonne CO2 annual reduction!
  • In 2020 we increased our total virtual visits (PC/SC/MH&AM) from 24% in 2019 to 55% of all visits. This led to a decrease in what we refer to as the "carbon intensity per appointment." Think of the impact this had on infrastructure, GHG emissions, and time loss from work.
  • With our PRN project, Wait Don’t Waste, we had soft and hard savings of approximately $1M in 2020 at 3 operating rooms (OR) from a combination of supplies not being picked or opened unless truly needed, and cleaning up OR surgeon cards to remove these one-offs from having to be picked. This environmentally friendly action shows environmental policies CAN make a financial impact on the operational budgets.
  • Our CAP identifies the importance of redundancy in our supply chain. COVID brought this to the fore as well (think masks and PPE from China, etc.). We are working with KP nationally to evolve our position on redundancy so that we can keep improving.

How can our employees personally step up?

We make a personal emissions calculator available to all of our employees to calculate their own carbon emissions from their home, their commute, or even a recent vacation.  They can then choose to offset those emissions right from within the calculator. Incidentally, calculating their personal emissions fulfills one of the requirements on this quarter's wellness passport, a keystone of our corporate wellness program.

NWP leading

This week our President and CEO Imelda Dacones, MD, joined Scott Becker on his podcast to discuss health and climate and published an op-ed in MedPage.
  • Listen to Imelda’s discussion with Scott Becker 
  • Read her article in MedPage

item.title: Perm Pod | Equity, Inclusion and Diversity: Building an inclusive workforce
item.dc:creator: jimthomson
item.content:encoded:
“It certainly starts at the top. Organizations and leadership teams have to be intentional about how they engage in diversity, equity and inclusion efforts.”

– Orlando Williams

One of our core values at Northwest Permanente is inclusion. We’ve made it a priority to ensure that more women, people of color, and other underrepresented groups are hired — and feel heard, respected, and connected once they join our physician and administrative teams. In the year since George Floyd’s murder, we’ve strengthened our commitment to equity, inclusion, and diversity in our workplace. To find out how we can continue to live our values and achieve our goals, our President and CEO, Imelda Dacones, MD, brought on her friend Orlando Williams for this episode of Perm Pod. Williams, the founder and CEO of MOTUS Staffing and Recruiting Inc., offered advice on building effective inclusion efforts: Make sure your leaders are well-trained in equity, diversity inclusion and speak the same language on the topic. Leaders should also learn the skill of cultural dexterity — the ability to work with people of many cultures by empathizing with their perspectives. For a practical, tactical approach, Williams offered the suggestion of creating a leadership council made up not only of company executives but also managers and frontline workers, so that the group reflects diverse points of view about the organization. The sweet spot: Keep the group to 25 or fewer members so everyone is heard. Guest: [caption id="attachment_1798" align="alignright" width="300"] Orlando Williams[/caption] Orlando Williams is an Oregon native and the president, chief executive officer, and chief equity officer at Motus Recruiting and Staffing, Inc. Williams started his recruiting career as an ambassador for prospective visiting athletes at the University of Oregon, then served as a player and Community Outreach Ambassador of Goodwill for the world-famous Harlem Globetrotters. He went on to work as a corporate recruiter at Nike World Headquarters, and to create the Oregon Diversity Recruiting Council, which offers strategies and training to recruit, retain, and promote BIPOC candidates in Oregon-based organizations. Host:  Imelda Dacones, MD, CEO and president, Northwest Permanente Materials/Resources:
  • Northwest Permanente Equity, Inclusion and Diversity
  • Motus Staffing and Recruiting Inc.
  • Oregon Diversity Recruiting Council

item.title: Women in medicine: We’ve got you!
item.dc:creator: jimthomson
item.content:encoded:
At Permanente Medicine, we’re committed to advancing equity, purpose, and joy in the practice of medicine. Recently, we were thrilled to host Permanente Women In Medicine, an inter-regional event designed to give women physicians and clinicians, and their allies, an opportunity to gather online and together explore tracks of leadership and allyship; laugh, cry, and have honest conversation; and connect to peers using an advanced virtual platform.

 

Nearly 1,800 men and women from 11 states joined us, June 11 to 13, with some regions holding concurrent local events in person.

 

The event included workshops, panels, networking, music, and surprise moments. PMWIM marks the beginning of what we hope becomes a tradition. We want to lead the way in creating a space for women and their allies in medicine to focus on leadership, allyship, and more.

  Until then, we encourage you to register to watch the plenary sessions on-demand.

item.title: Thank you and farewell to Dr. Imelda Dacones
item.dc:creator: jimthomson
item.content:encoded: Thank you and farewell to Dr. Imelda Dacones This week, we bid farewell to Imelda Dacones, MD, who has served as Northwest Permanente’s President and CEO for the last six years and has spent the entirety of her 22-year post-residency career in our NWP family. She is leaving Northwest Permanente to relocate to the Seattle area with her family. Dr. Dacones’ tenure has been marked with significant clinical, operational, and fiscal advances toward Northwest Permanente’s mission to build total health in the communities we serve. Called to medicine from a young age, Dr. Dacones has, throughout her career, sustained an uncompromising vision to transform health care and build healthy, inclusive, and engaged communities. Beyond her accomplishments in leading Northwest Permanente to deliver medical excellence and the highest quality patient care, Dr. Dacones recognizes the critical need to take care delivery beyond the clinic and into the communities our medical group serves. From the national physician sponsor for Kaiser Permanente’s innovative “Thrive Local” program, designed to address critical gaps in patients’ social needs, to her service on the board of the Virginia Garcia Memorial Health Center Foundation, a civic organization committed to providing access to health care for those who need it most, to overseeing the development of new protocols to screen for and address adverse childhood events (ACEs), Dr. Dacones is both an outspoken advocate and innovator in our understanding of the social and environmental determinants of health.  Within Northwest Permanente, Dr. Dacones has been committed to building a culture of innovation, transformation, and engagement. Under her leadership, Northwest Permanente became the world’s first physician group to achieve B Corp status, actively demonstrating a strong corporate commitment to use business as a force for good. For four years running, Northwest Permanente has been ranked among the top 10 percent of all certified B Corps and earned a “Best for the World” designation. Dr. Dacones’ values-driven approach has had an impact on our workforce: An annual engagement survey reflected growth in employee engagement by 31 percentage points to an overall 70% engagement rate, which stands in stark contrast to standard industry benchmarks that suggest over 70% of the U.S. workforce is disengaged at work.  And, Northwest Permanente physicians are respected by their peers: 198 NWP physicians made Portland Monthly 2020 Top Docs’ annual peer-vetted list, more than any other health care organization or physician group in the state for adult medical and surgical specialties.  During Dr. Dacones’ leadership, Kaiser Permanente’s Sunnyside Medical Center (SMC) and Westside Medical Center (WMC) have consistently received the highest rankings for both safety and quality of care. Both hospitals have received Leapfrog “A” ratings for hospital safety since 2018 — only about a third of hospitals graded receive this rating. For care of both lung cancer and heart patients, the Society of Thoracic Surgeons has awarded the Kaiser Permanente Northwest cardiothoracic surgery teams with 3 stars, the highest overall composite score of hospitals nationwide. Sunnyside is one of 18 U.S. hospitals that earned top scores by Consumer Reports for both bypass and valve replacement surgery. Both hospitals made U.S. News & World Report’s annual “Best Hospitals” report for several key areas: SMC, for aortic valve surgery, COPD, colon cancer surgery, heart bypass surgery, and congestive heart failure, and WMC for hip and knee surgeries. In 2020, both hospitals received the “2020 Get With The Guidelines® - Stroke Gold Plus Award” achievement from the American Stroke Association. As only the second female Chief Executive Officer in Northwest Permanente's 75-year history, and a first-generation immigrant to this country, Dr. Dacones has been an inspiring and outspoken advocate for equity, inclusion, and diversity in the health care sector and beyond. She actively works to dismantle gender bias in medicine and promote anti-bias training and culturally responsive practices. During her tenure as CEO, she has hired five women leaders into executive roles (C-Suite or VP) to secure a 50/50 female-to-male ratio across the company’s senior leadership. In addition, she participates in a mentorship program for emerging female physician leaders. In 2020, she was named one of Modern Healthcare’s Top 25 Minority Leaders in health care across the nation. We could not be more grateful to Dr. Dacones for her outstanding leadership! Northwest Permanente plans to select Dr. Dacones’ successor this fall and has named Dr. Tom Hickey as Interim CEO and President. Dr. Hickey brings a wealth of experience to the role, having previously served as Northwest Permanente’s COO as well as Washington Permanente Group’s COO, as well as a practicing family medicine physician with Northwest Permanente for over 30 years.

item.title: Are you a CRNA looking to join a dynamic, supportive team? Come chat with us!
item.dc:creator: jimthomson
item.content:encoded:
Are you a CRNA looking to join an awesome and dynamic supportive team? Come chat with us!

Who we are: Northwest Permanente is the largest self-governed, multispecialty medical group in Oregon and Southwest Washington, delivering high-quality, innovative care in the region for more than 80 years. Northwest Permanente is made up of more than 1,500 physicians, clinicians, and sub-specialists in virtually every area of medical and surgical practice. With an integrated health care model, Northwest Permanente is a patient-centered practice that serves more than 630,000 Kaiser Permanente members across the region. Hear from a few of our CRNAs about why they choose to work here [caption id="attachment_1828" align="alignleft" width="147"] Emelia Hutto, CRNA[/caption] CRNA Emelia Hutto came to work at Northwest Permanente for multiple reasons. "The team was friendly and genuinely interested in me as a person — beyond anesthesia. They made me feel as though I was not only going to work at a great organization but to work and show up as part of a team.” Hutto has been part of the NWP team for over 2 years now. “I'm glad I decided to join NWP. The organization prioritizes work-life balance and supports me in pursuing opportunities to develop my career as well.     [caption id="attachment_1829" align="alignright" width="147"] David Kallberg, CRNA[/caption] CRNA David Kallberg gained his initial impression of Northwest Permanente as a student anesthetist. “I witnessed the team’s excellent work and cohesiveness as a department.” Specifically, he was impressed by the collegial atmosphere and the interpersonal interactions, which ultimately lead him to a career at NWP. "People were happy, friendly, and put the patient first.” “We enjoy a great relationship with one another as CRNA colleagues," David says. "We take care of each other, give breaks, assist each other if we're not busy. We also maintain great working relationships with our anesthesiologist partners. Despite working in a supervised capacity, we are respected and trusted members of the team and have a high degree of autonomy.”   When you join Northwest Permanente you’re joining a B Corp, a company that prioritizes its community, its employees, and the environment — balancing profit and purpose. In 2021, B Lab recognized our commitment to one another with a Best for the World designation! Other perks our CRNAs enjoy:
  • A welcoming and inclusive culture
  • Differential pay, sign-on bonuses, relocation assistance
  • A physician and clinician-led practice that puts patients first, providing best-in-class care
  • Meaningful rewards, including industry-leading benefits and growth opportunities
Learn more about what sets the CRNA team at Northwest Permanente apart. Reach out to Senior Recruiter Jason Obilana, who can tell you more about the unparalleled opportunities we offer for a meaningful and rewarding career in medicine. [caption id="attachment_1849" align="alignleft" width="1024"] NWP CRNA Christina Lippert having fun in the Pacific Northwest[/caption]

item.title: 'This is the doctor who saved you'
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_1845" align="alignright" width="150"] Lisa Denike, MD[/caption] Lisa Denike, MD, is the Chief of Pediatrics here at Kaiser Permanente Northwest, and in that role she sometimes fills in for other physicians on her team. That's what happened one day last December when she took care of a young man with an earache. Turns out that 14-year-old Alex had seen Dr. Denike on another occasion when she was filling in for his regular doctor. When he was just 2 weeks old, she'd helped to diagnose him with a respiratory syncytial virus, or RSV. As a result, he spent 5 days in the neonatal intensive care unit. Alex eventually recovered and, despite having asthma, grew up a relatively healthy kid. But as you might imagine, the experience left a huge impression on his mother, Amber. [caption id="attachment_1844" align="alignright" width="660"] Amber and Alex[/caption] “When I saw [Dr. Denike], I had tears streaming down my face,” she said. “I couldn’t contain myself, I was so happy to see her.” As a pediatric patient, Alex is taken care of as part of our innovative Thriving Families initiative, a comprehensive pediatric program designed to provide cohesive care for kids from birth through the teenage years. “We’ve developed standardized care and information, and facilitate collaboration between pediatrics, ob-gyn, and family medicine to try to make the patient experience consistent across those departments and to have robust communication between those departments,” says Dr. Denike. Read more about Alex, Amber, and Dr. Denike — and Thriving Families  — in Portland Monthly.

item.title: Find NWP doctors on Instagram, talking about climate change and health, and vaccines
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_1864" align="alignright" width="250"] Host Alex McDonald, MD, top, chats with NWP EM physician Edward Lew, MD.[/caption] Our physician leadership doesn’t stop at the doors of our clinics. Recently a couple of Northwest Permanente physicians had opportunities to go live in Instagram chats sponsored by Permanente Medicine to discuss two of the most important topics currently relevant to our patients: vaccines and climate change. A few weeks ago, Emergency Medicine physician Edward Lew, MD, joined host Alex McDonald, MD, to discuss COVID-19 in the ER, younger patients who are becoming more symptomatic, and the importance of discussing COVID-19 vaccines at each medical system touch point. Next, Colin Cave, MD, a head and neck surgeon who is also NWP's medical director of external affairs, government relations and community health, joined Dr. McDonald to discuss climate change and health, the global supply chain, and how health systems can make a difference. You can watch replays of both of these short, important discussions at the links provided, even without an Instagram account.

item.title: Telling her story: One NWP physician's life during the pandemic
item.dc:creator: jimthomson
item.content:encoded:
Sasha Mallett, MD, a Northwest Permanente physician whose primary care practice has become 100 percent virtual since the start of the pandemic, has just published an essay in the New England Journal of Medicine about her very unique and challenging experience during COVID. [caption id="attachment_1872" align="alignright" width="519"] Dr. Mallett's story was featured on the local public radio station. Credit: Kristyna Wentz-Graff / OPB[/caption] Since the birth of her son 5 years ago, Dr. Mallett has lived with an autoimmune disease called Sjögren’s and a rare immunodeficiency called CVID (common variable immunodeficiency). "If you made a list of illnesses not to get during a pandemic, CVID would probably be near the top," she writes. Long interested in storytelling and Narrative Medicine, Dr. Mallett recognizes the benefit of sharing her personal story. In addition to the NEJM essay, she had the opportunity to talk about her experience recently on Oregon Public Broadcasting. Discussing the challenges of her life has felt like a sort of “coming out,” she said. "Prior to COVID, I hadn’t disclosed my health conditions to any of my work colleagues or patients," she said. "But since sharing my story, I’ve received over 120 emails from strangers around the world in relatable situations, along with handwritten cards and emails from my patients voicing their support, and numerous emails from work colleagues commending me for my bravery." Dr. Mallett focuses the NEJM essay on her young son's first day of school, a stressor that many parents can relate to. "I realize that our family’s situation adds an extra twist," she says.
So I offer this plea to my son, the universe, or any other parties that may be in charge: please, send him home each day with his backpack full of craft projects and letter-writing exercises. Send him home with insights about the world, new friends, and a willingness to share. And if it’s not too much to ask, please do not send him home with Covid. I worry that the mechanical parts of me that have been fighting so hard for years to remain intact might finally break, and if possible, I would like to continue being his mom for a good while longer." Sasha Mallett, MD, "Peak Moments — When Kindergarten Is High Risk
"You never know how sharing something so personal will land," Dr. Mallett said. "I had to summon a good bit of courage to broadcast so publicly these stories about my disability. But I am so grateful with how well they have been received, both personally and professionally." Post updated: Dr. Mallett was a featured guest on the New England Journal of Medicine podcast as well on October 21st.
Connect with Dr. Mallett via her website, SashaMallett.com.

item.title: Are you an Occupational Medicine physician looking to join a collaborative and supportive team?
item.dc:creator: jimthomson
item.content:encoded:
Our Occupational Medicine Department has openings!

Northwest Permanente is the largest physician-led, multispecialty medical group in Oregon and Southwest Washington, with an 80-year history of delivering high-quality, innovative care. Northwest Permanente comprises more than 1,500 physicians, clinicians, and subspecialists in virtually every area of medical and surgical practice. Our integrated health care model is a patient-centered practice that serves more than 630,000 Kaiser Permanente members across the region. Our physicians enjoy:
  • A welcoming and inclusive culture
  • A physician-led practice that puts patients first, providing best-in-class care
  • Meaningful rewards, including industry-leading benefits and growth opportunities
Northwest Permanente is a B Corp, a company that prioritizes its community, its employees, and the environment — balancing profit and purpose. In 2021, B Lab recognized our commitment with a Best for the World designation. Reach out to Senior Recruiter Shana Klemchuk for more about the opportunities we offer for a meaningful and rewarding career in medicine.
Hear from a few of our Occupational Medicine physicians about why they choose to work here: [caption id="attachment_1882" align="alignleft" width="340" class="width= "] Kevin Loh, DO[/caption] I joined Northwest Permanente because I wanted to live in the Pacific Northwest after transitioning from active-duty military. I also was very impressed by the retirement benefits and health insurance that Northwest Permanente and Kaiser Permanente provide. Northwest Permanente values work-life balance, allowing me to prioritize my family. On the Occupational Medicine team, we work very hard and also enjoy the work we do. The Occupational Medicine team is a great group and, when needed, staff will step in and cover each other. Indeed, I found that NWP (not just Occupational Medicine but the whole organization) emphasizes teamwork, which is quite impressive. I genuinely enjoy working here and love my coworkers — not just in my department but overall, within Kaiser Permanente.      
[caption id="attachment_1886" align="alignright" width="340"] Amy Hinrichs, MD[/caption] I chose a career at Northwest Permanente because I was very attracted to working in a genuinely physician-led group. I have found the collegiality among NWP clinicians makes even the most challenging days feel rewarding — we are all on the same team trying to deliver excellent care. The organization stands behind that and contributes to the community in material ways; we are a certified B Corp, support social determinants of health and social justice causes, and promote physician leadership in government affairs. Work-life balance is essential to me. That means I have all the tools to provide excellent care for my patients at work, such as administrative support, evidence-based practice guidelines, legal consultation, case management, and efficient clinical workflows. When I’m not at work, I can truly relax. I don’t worry about marketing, billing, legal exposure, scheduling — I get to focus my attention on physician work. I am also supported by generous paid time off, and I have peace of mind working in a group. I can take a vacation knowing that competent and caring colleagues will address any emergencies with my patients. Our culture supports having a life outside of work, from the top down. The Occupational Medicine team at NWP is different because it supports holistic care that considers the patient’s entire health journey. Because we are embedded in a large health care organization (including a patient’s primary care home), we have insight and relationships with primary and specialty care that give us a much more sophisticated understanding of each patient’s clinical picture. Our team is incented to do the right thing for the patient, not the fastest way to make a profit. We are all board-certified in occupational medicine, so we can practice at the highest level of the specialty, rather than merely providing urgent care services.
[caption id="attachment_1883" align="alignleft" width="340" class="width= "] Matthew Campbell, MD[/caption] I joined Northwest Permanente because I was impressed by the natural beauty of the Pacific Northwest — and the job benefits were also a big draw. I bought a house before I even started work, and luckily it turned out I loved working here too. I appreciate that I have time and energy to enjoy life outside of work. The work shifts are very manageable, and all the support I receive from the staff, administration, and other clinicians, keeps me from feeling drained at the end of my workdays. The Occupational Medicine Department is growing and evolving at NWP. We just moved into new clinics located with Physical Therapy. Working closely with PT will allow better coordination and improve patient care. It’s great to be able to discuss patients with our PT colleagues. Since the practice is changing, it’s an exciting time to be here, and there is ample opportunity for new physicians to have input and help direct changes.     [caption id="attachment_1829" align="aligncenter" width="500" class=" width= "] Matthew Campbell, MD, with his fiancee and dog, enjoying the Pacific Northwest[/caption]

item.title: Salud en Español team re-engineers the diabetes care visit
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded:
Within Kaiser Permanente Northwest, our Latino/a/x patients are at high risk for diabetes mellitus (DM), and in fact are one of our populations having the highest risk. This population also experiences significant barriers to access care, for reasons that may include:
  • Low health literacy
  • Suspicion of medical system
  • Demanding and essential work
  • Difficulty coordinating visits and follow up given language and technology barriers
DM not only is very prevalent in this population, but also higher rates of poor DM control and poor outcomes related to DM complications are more likely as well. Given these circumstances, the Sunset Medical Office’s Salud en Español team, under the leadership of Saskia van der Wal, MD, created the Integrative Diabetes Clinic Pilot, a program for reducing DM among the population served by Salud. The pilot started in May and is approved to run through December.

How it works

The team created an integrative DM-focused care experience for these patients that differs from the typical care experience. [caption id="attachment_1890" align="alignright" width="350"] Provisions are supplied by the Sunset Medical Office and local food pantries.[/caption] For one half day per month, the team selects 10-11 diabetic Spanish-speaking patients, 6 of whom receive an additional visit that follows their regular appointment. These visits are conducted by a Spanish-speaking Behavioral Health Consultant, a Health Educator, or another bilingual staff member. These DM visits are virtual and are conducted from an exam room on site to facilitate a smooth video visit (using our KP office/exam room equipment and not the patient’s phone). Outreach involves actively running the DM list with select chart reviews by Primary Care physicians and others, working with Dr. van der Wal. The initial focus was on patients with A1c>8; Spanish-speaking DM patients from other clinicians at Sunset could also be referred. For each visit, a dedicated bilingual scheduler, who is available off hours and can make multiple attempts to reach the patients, is used. Patients receive reminder calls 1-2 days before their appointment. Before the clinic, team members join a brief (15-minute) huddle, to facilitate a warm handoff process (MA, BHC, HEWS, MD). Finally, to promote healthy eating, food boxes are offered to each clinic patient. These contain a diabetic-friendly mix of grains, legumes, proteins, fruits, and veggies. (The food is provided through donations from local food banks and Sunset Medical Office.)

The clinic's success

Outcomes data from this pilot are pending review, but Dr. van der Wal is enthusiastic. [caption id="attachment_1630" align="alignleft" width="130"] Dr. van der Wal[/caption] “I have been blown away by the impact of this clinic,” she said. “Not only are patients more engaged, they are so appreciative to have services integrated into one visit and love the food provisions.” Over the long term, Dr. van der Wal has a vision of turning the pilot into an integrated diabetes group visit with rotating cohorts that can support each other and experience different educational topics related to DM (everything from DM basics to cooking classes to movement sessions and stress management). “The surprising piece for me is how I personally feel more excited about diabetes care in this non-traditional care-delivery style,” she said. “I had found that the traditional medical office visit for chronic diabetes management just wasn’t working for me or my patients. This works better.”

item.title: Congratulations to our 2022 Top Docs and Nurses
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded:
As they do every year, Portland Monthly has once again published their list of Top Medical Providers, which includes physicians and other clinicians. KPNW clinicians had a strong showing of 215 individuals recognized by their peers as clinicians whom they would want taking care of themselves or their family members. NWP CEO and President Leong Koh, MD, wrote, "Over the course of my nearly two decades with Northwest Permanente, the depth of talent, expertise, compassion, and care among our physicians has always made me proud to practice among this team. Whether for our clinical excellence, our focus on the unique needs of each individual patient, or the vigilance with which we address safety measures across the continuum, our physicians and clinicians truly are top tier. "My hearty congratulations to all of the 2021 Top Docs and Nurses! Your work shines bright, and this community-wide recognition is well-deserved."
Image courtesy Portland Monthly
item.excerpt:encoded: More than 200 of our clinicians and physicians are among the region's Top Medical Providers for 2022, as recognized by Portland Monthly magazine.

item.title: New podcast by NWP physician explores mindset and healing
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded: In her 15-year career at Northwest Permanente, Katie Deming, MD, has helped care for thousands of patients who have cancer. As a physician, she's noticed that some patients do better with their illness and others do worse. Much of the difference she sees in her patients' outcomes is related to their mindset and how they approach their illness. Over the past year, drawing on her background in neuroscience and biopsychology, Dr. Deming took time to immerse herself in the study of the mind, familiarizing herself with data that has emerged over the last decade on healing and the mind. Now — in an effort to share when she's learned about the importance of mindset in healing — she has created a podcast. Born to Heal, already at 16 episodes, is widely available. It explores a variety of topics that may be of special interest to cancer patients — but also to others as well. "I was pleasantly surprised to find so much evidence to support the power of the mind in healing," she said. "I now incorporate this knowledge into my practice. This podcast is a way for me to share my knowledge more broadly." Dr. Deming is striking a chord: Her podcast has received 59 ratings on Apple Podcasts, all 5-stars.

item.title: NWP clinicians honor the legacy of Martin Luther King, Jr.
item.dc:creator: k.gordon
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_1938" align="alignright" width="300"] Dr. Shaw, Dr. Sailler, and Dr. Sorweide at the Salem Free Clinic[/caption] From Salem, Oregon, to Longview, Washington, our Northwest Permanente physicians and clinicians delivered both medical treatment and compassion for Kaiser Permanente's MLK Days of Service (January 13-21). Even before the pandemic, this was a popular community service activity among NWP clinicians. This year, despite their own pandemic burnout, they were still quick to sign up for the MLK Days of Service, using a "paid day on" to meet the medical needs of patients in 6 of our community-partner clinics:
  • Salem Free Clinic
  • Community Health Partners in Longview
  • Free Clinic of SW Washington
  • Battle Ground Health Care
  • Clackamas Volunteers in Medicine
  • Springfield Volunteers in Medicine
Along with medical care, patients who needed vision services received free eye exams from NWP optometrists and glasses at Kaiser Permanente Vision Essentials clinics throughout the region. While our clinicians at the free clinics served medical and vision needs, our colleagues at Permanente Dental Associates provided free dental care to community members. Finally, KPNW  partnered with Sunshine Division to distribute free food boxes. A KPNW donation of $90,000 provided 3,000 meals to those in need in Cowlitz, Clark, Washington, Clackamas and Marion counties. The MLK Days of Service events underscore Northwest Permanente's long-standing commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion. Participating in these important activities is just one of the many ways we fulfill our mission to improve the health of our communities. Thank you to all who participated in the 2022 MLK Days of Service! Your efforts are appreciated!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Northwest Permanente physicians delivered medical treatment and compassion to the area’s most underserved communities.

item.title: NWP Innovation in action: Telehealth for prenatal care
item.dc:creator: k.gordon
item.content:encoded: A smart phone. A scale. A blood pressure cuff. And a fetal heartrate doppler monitor. With the carefully coordinated and Bluetooth-enabled technology of Northwest Permanente’s newest innovation, that’s all that’s needed for our obstetrical patients to see their physicians virtually. Beginning February 21, a comprehensive virtual prenatal care program will be available for low-risk prenatal patients, thanks to the collaboration and innovation of our Northwest Permanente physician leaders and coordinated departments. Offering a blend of virtual and in-person perinatal visits, KP Connected Pregnancy Care is a new care pathway for many of our perinatal patients. The program is supported by a mobile app and remote patient monitoring tools; it promises to improve access and efficiency for both members and care teams. NWP leaders who championed this cutting-edge care model include Emily West, MD, physician co-lead of The Pregnancy Journey for the Thriving Family Service Line (TFSL); Stacie Sobiesczyk, former TFSL program manager; Shelly Erkenbeck, practice director; Jennifer Rupert, MD, Chief of Ob-Gyn; and Eric Warshaw, MD, director of operations. The collaborative and innovative project was also made possible through the partnership with the Department of Medical Informatics (DMI) and Michael McNamara, MD,  Rahul Rastogi, MD, and Jillian Croslin, program manager, who set up the remote patient monitoring equipment necessary for the program. With a blood pressure cuff and scale that are Bluetooth compatible, the patient’s vitals will flow into EPIC utilizing the HealthAlly App. Prenatal patients will also be instructed to use fetal dopplers at home, making it feasible for every other visit to be in-person. KP Connected Pregnancy Care offers many benefits to prenatal members, including reduced exposure to COVID, reduced travel and time spent away from family and work responsibilities, and increased access to visits, improving the ability for family members to participate. The hybrid virtual care program also offers efficiency and time savings for care teams and clinicians, while allowing them to meet patients where they are and increase connections to members. “Once the program is well established with low-risk patients, we hope to expand it to some high-risk patients, including those with hypertension,” says Dr. Rupert. “For now, we look forward to improving access to care for our lower-risk prenatal patients and their families.” And that’s a step in the direction of better health for all.
item.excerpt:encoded: a comprehensive virtual prenatal care program will be available for low-risk prenatal patients, thanks to the collaboration and innovation of our Northwest Permanente physician leaders and coordinated departments.

item.title: Webinar focused on acute care at home
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded:
UPDATED! Read more about this webinar, where Mary Giswold, MD, Northwest Permanente chief operating officer, gave an in-depth look at the advanced-care-at-home program here at Kaiser Permanente of the Northwest.       The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the possibility, and the necessity, of acute-level care at home. With challenges such as hospital capacity and an aging population, the health care industry must look for innovative, sustainable ways to deliver safe, high-quality, equitable care today and in the future. Register for “Permanente Live: The revolution and evolution of acute care at home,” a free webinar on March 15, 2022, 10 a.m. PT/1 p.m. ET. Physician leaders, including Northwest Permanente's own Mary Giswold, MD, will share the latest in acute-care-at-home programs; discuss how they foster person-centered care and the changing roles of care team members; and examine the challenges and solutions for access, social health, and equitable care. Featured speakers:
  • Stephen M. Parodi, MD (moderator), executive vice president of External Affairs, Communications and Brand, The Permanente Federation; associate executive director, The Permanente Medical Group
  • Mary Giswold, MD, chief operating officer, Northwest Permanente
  • David Levine, MD, medical director, Strategy and Innovation, Brigham and Women’s Home Hospital
  • Michael Maniaci, MD, enterprise physician lead and medical director, Advanced Care at Home, Mayo Clinic
  • Sarita Mohanty, MD, MPH, president and CEO, The SCAN Foundation
Register now for this complimentary webinar (space limited). Registrants will have exclusive access to the on-demand replay recording afterward.

item.title: NWP announces TFME scholarship winners
item.dc:creator: jimthomson
item.content:encoded: At Northwest Permanente, we're committed to diversity in our workforce and proudly support medical education and the workforce of the future. That's why we're excited to partner again with the Foundation for Medical Excellence (TFME) to award scholarships to two local third-year medical students: Joel Bervell Joel attended Yale University and then received a Master of Medical Science degree from Boston University. He plans to graduate from Washington State University's Elson S. Floyd College of Medicine in June 2023. Among his many achievements, Joel has co-created an international non-profit “Hugs for Ghana,” worked as a mentor for high school students, assisted with technology applications for his classmates, and conducted research in orthopedic medicine. He's also created more than 350 short-form videos on health tips and racial bias in medicine. He's received multiple honors and awards for his work as a conversational change maker and creator. After medical school, he plans to pursue a career in surgery. His creativity and passion for honest dialogue and his commitment cultural intelligence made him a clear choice for this award. Shirin Ferdosian Najafabadi Shirin attended Portland Community College and Portland State University before matriculating at Oregon Health & Science University, where she plans to graduate in June 2023. She emigrated to the United States from Iran as a non-native English speaker and worked a variety of jobs — as a home care provider, medical interpreter, and medical billing specialist, among others — before entering medical school. Shirin has a deep passion for developing herself and other women as leaders in medicine. Her application essay and letters of recommendation underscore her deep understanding the dynamics of the patient/physician relationship in health care delivery.     About the Foundation for Medical Excellence Created in 1984, the Foundation for Medical Excellence is dedicated to improving the health of the public through health care professional education and the development of innovative health policy. The Foundation is recognized by the health care community in our region as a neutral venue for the discussion of health care related issues. NWP Internal Medicine physician Ellen Singer, MD, currently serves as its medical director.

item.title: Our 2021 Company Impact Report: How we showed up
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded: Welcome to our annual impact report, which tells the story of our medical group through a year we won't soon forget. From the spring's All4Oregon vaccine center that facilitated a half a million shots in arms, to a smooth and swift transition of leadership, to the incredible and creative ways in which our teams showed up for one another — it was a remarkable year. The COVID-19 pandemic brought major shifts to our practice, one of which is our hospital at home program. Begun in 2020, our hospital at home program picked up speed in 2021, and by year's end, nearly 1,100 patients had received hospital-level care in the comfort of their own surroundings — with the love and support of their families nearby. We're hearing from our patients that they love this option, and it provided capacity and flexibility during a time our community desperately needed it. It's a great example of our culture of innovation at work. Another bright spot was the Peer Supporters program, about which you will read more in the report. These clinicians volunteer to serve as witnesses and resources for their colleagues — in an unquantifiable measure of respect and kindness. As a Northwest Permanente physician for almost 20 years, I could not be more proud of our medical group and the efforts of every physician, clinician, and member of our administrative team — always, but especially during the COVID pandemic. You — they — are all health care heroes.     Leong Koh, MD CEO and President

item.title: 'Wait, Don't Waste' helps our surgeons take a pause
item.dc:creator: kimcarlson
item.content:encoded: This Earth Day, and every day, our physicians recognize the connection between the health of the planet and the health of all of us. Listen to this week's PermanenteDocs Facebook Live chat. NWP surgeon Sande Irwin, MD, talks about Wait Don't Waste, a program here at Northwest Permanente in which our surgery teams carefully gauge product usage in operating rooms. "I can be a driver as a physician. So I want to be thoughtful about what I ask for...what I use...can I wait, not waste?"
item.excerpt:encoded: Learn about how we're reducing waste in operating rooms.

item.title: Connect with us! ACP and AOHC Conference Updates
item.dc:creator: k.gordon
item.content:encoded: After a two-year hiatus due to COVID-19, our Northwest Permanente recruiters and physicians are attending conferences once again. Last week, Senior Recruiter Marisa Walters connected with other Permanente Medicine Groups and attendees of the American College of Physicians Conference Mastering Medicine Together in Chicago, Illinois. This week,  Amy Hinrichs, MD and  Senior Recruiter Shana Klemchuk are attending the American Occupational Health Conference in Salt Lake City, Utah -- both in person and virtually. More conferences and annual meetings are on the calendar the remainder of the spring and summer. We look forward to connecting with you! Learn more about Occupational Medicine at Northwest Permanente

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Northwest Permanente joins ACP and AOHC Conferences in April and May 2022. Great to see you all again!
